Not for Redistribution P A RT I ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution This page intentionally left blank ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution I. Introduction In 1970 there continued to be a rapid expan- sion in world trade. In terms of total value, the 1969-70 increase amounted to slightly more than 14 per cent, about the same rate of expansion as that recorded for the previous year. For industrial countries as a group, both imports and exports rose by some 15-16 per cent, while the increase in trade of primary producing countries was on the order of 10-11 per cent. Of the increase in the value of world exports in 1970, slightly less than half was a reflection of higher prices, particularly for manufac tured prod- ucts, rather than of increased volume. Prices of primary products rose considerably less steeply, on the average, than those of manufactures. Al- though food prices registered an increase ap- proaching the average rate for manufactured goods, the trend in prices of most other primary products was much weaker, as those of base metals showed little change and those of agricul- tural raw materials declined appreciably. The changes in the restrictive systems of mem- ber countries that took place in the period under review, although not affecting a major portion of world payments, appear on balance to have re- sulted in a reduction in restrictions on current payments. This occurred despite the difficulties in the world payments system witnessed in 1968 and 1969. At the end of 1970 there were somewhat less than 10 members out of a total of 117 whose restrictive systems could be described as complex as regards their rate structure or their exchange systems as a whole. Several important reforms took place, in Ecuador, Indonesia, the Philippines, Turkey, and Viet-Nam in 1970 and in Yugoslavia in early 1971. These reforms led to simplifica- tions of restrictive systems and to a relaxation of general restrictions. France, in two successive steps, relaxed tourist allowances in 1970, and this action was followed by a number of the Opera- tions Account countries.2 Early in 1971 France 1 The period under review in this Report covers 1970 and the ea r ly pa rt of 1971. 2 Countries whose institute of issue maintains an Operations Account with the French Treasury: Cam- eroon, Central A f r ican Republic, Chad, People's Repub- lic of the Congo, Dahomey, Gabon, Ivory Coast, Mala- gasy Republic, Mali, Mauritania, Niger, Senegal, Togo, and Upper Volta. again increased its tourist allowances. Other coun- tries, both developed and developing, each as a group, also increased their tourist allowances. These relaxations of restrictions were aided by an increase in 1970 in the international reserves in developed and developing countries, as a group. In addition to the relaxations in exchange restric- tions and the exchange reforms undertaken, the resort to bilateral payments agreements also de- clined in the period. In the sphere of nontariff trade barriers, however, the situation is less clear. With regard to import surcharges, advance im- port deposits, and measures to stimulate exports, there appears to have been a small net increase in restrictions. Also, in several member countries the role of state trading increased. Although it is difficult to quan t ify the effect of this, it is possible that on balance there was an increase in restric- tions insofar as nontariff barriers are concerned. In its consultations and through the provision of financial resources, especially in support of stand-by arrangements, the Fund has continued to work for a multilateral trade and payments system based on effective par values and free from restrictions on current payments. In addition, in the past year the Fund reviewed its policy with respect to the granting of temporary approvals of multiple currency practices and of restrictions on payments and transfers for current in terna t ional transactions that are subject to approval under the Fund's Articles of Agreement. The review centered on the need for uniformity of approach in granting approval and the importance of grant- ing approval only for a specified time normally not to exceed 12 months. The approval policy with respect to undue delays in mak ing exchange available for the settlement of current in te rna- tional transactions that result from a govern- mental l im i ta t ion and give rise to payments ar- rears was the subject of a separate review. Such delays are payments restrictions under Arti- cle VIII, Section 2(a) and Article XIV, Section 2 of the Fund Agreement, whether the limitation is formalized, as for instance by the imposition of compulsory wa i t ing periods for exchange, or is in fo rmal or ad hoc. As a result of its review, the Fund adopted a decision which drew attention to the particular harm that informal or ad hoc meas- 1 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution REPORT ON EXCHANGE RESTRICTIONS ures that undu ly delay the availability or use of exchange for current international transactions do to a country's financial relationships because of the uncertainty they generate. The Fund provided general guidelines for their treatment. These guidelines made provision for the possibility of Fund approval of the exchange restriction, to- gether with financial assistance by the Fund to support a program which inter alia envisages a phasing out of the restriction. Of major potential importance for trade and payments prospects of the developing countries was the agreement in principle reached within the United Nations Conference on Trade and Devel- opment on a system of generalized preferences in their favor to be implemented in 1971. Proposals are pending in the United Nations that developed countries shall not raise any new tariff and non- tariff barriers to primary products from develop- ing countries, and that existing tariff barriers to imports of manufactures and semimanufactures of interest to developing countries are to be elimi- nated progressively (Strategy for the Second De- velopment Decade). Also of importance was a High-Level Meeting in Tokyo of the Development Assistance Committee (DAC), at which a majority of donor countries expressed support for the prin- ciple of un ty ing bilateral and multilateral aid. Two countries —the Yemen Arab Republic and Barbados —became members of the Fund in 1970, raising the total membership to 117 poun- tries at the end of the year. During the period under review Ecuador accepted the obligations of Article VIII, which have now been accepted by 35 member countries accounting for some three fourths of world trade. Par values were changed by Ecuador and Turkey in 1970 and by Yugo- slavia in early 1971. Initial par values were estab- lished by the Republic of China and the Demo- cratic Republic of Congo. On May 31, 1970, Canada announced that it would, for the time being, not maintain the exchange rate of the Canadian dollar within the permitted margins, i.e., the exchange rate of the Canadian dollar has been allowed to fluctuate. The Fund has since been in close consultation with Canada on the question of the re-establishment of an effective par value. This Report, and in particular the following sections, centers on exchange restrictions, but it also covers other measures and intergovernmental arrangements that may have direct balance of 2 payments implications, such as import deposits, import surcharges, and measures to stimulate exports. II. Main Developments in Restrictive Practices Trade and Payments Restrictions Restrictions on Imports and Import Payments Among industrialized countries, some further relaxation of import restrictions took place, mainly in the United States (for crude and fuel oil from Canada and Venezuela), the United Kingdom (for imports from the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance (CMEA) coun- tries 3 and imports of coal), France (for imports from CMEA countries and for imports of North African wine), Germany (formal liberalization of most commodities of CMEA origin, although most already were liberalized de facto), Italy (for im- ports from CMEA countries), the Netherlands ( for imports from CMEA countries), and Israel and Japan (specified items from all sources). Den- mark reorganized its import controls, a move which involved additional liberalization of imports from CMEA sources and to some extent also from other sources, e.g., for coffee. Japan in addition decided to accelerate its liberalization program. New Zealand liberalized to the point where license-free commodities account for about two thirds of private imports. South Africa continued liberalization of import restrictions following dis- invocation of Article XII of the General Agree- ment on Tariffs and Trade (GATT). With the greatly reduced scope of quantitative restrictions and the tariff reductions resulting from the Kennedy Round, attention is now being given increasingly to the problem of the remaining non- tariff barriers. Among developing countries, many felt con- strained by balance of payments considerations not to relax import restrictions significantly. The following are some of the countries that did lib- eralize appreciably. Colombia and Uruguay added a number of commodities to the free list, and Chile expanded its permitted list on several occa- sions during 1970. Colombia, in addition, licensed controlled imports more liberally and reduced the 3 A lban ia, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Eastern Germany, Hungary, Mongolia, Poland, Ruman ia, and U.S.S.R. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MAIN DEVELOPMENTS IN RESTRICTIVE PRACTICES coverage of its list of prohibited imports. Some liberalization occurred in China, Ghana, and Morocco. The Philippines relaxed its restrictions on imports and import payments when it floated the peso. Cameroon abolished all quotas under its 1971 import program and replaced them with a small list of goods for which prior authorization is necessary before they can be imported. Some import liberalization took place in Turkey after the change in par value. The backlog of exchange applications was eliminated by the end of 1970 and under the new import regime for 1971 a sub- stantial percentage of imports was freed from re- strictions. Developing countries that tightened import re- strictions included the following. Algeria took fur- ther measures to curb imports classified as non- essential. The Khmer Republic sharply reduced allocations of official foreign exchange for im- ports. Peru in March 1970 extended for an in- definite period its prohibition on the import of goods listed as nonessential. Ceylon revoked the open general license for imports and made the former open general license items subject to quotas. Tanzania in August 1970 made many open general license goods subject to specific im- port license. Indonesia added some further import prohibitions, although the list remains short and Indonesia otherwise maintains an import system free of restrictions. A number of developing coun- tries that maintain relatively minor import restric- tions, and some of which have stated that they maintain these primarily for protective reasons, continued their policy of gradually subjecting ad- ditional commodities to an individual import license; these countries included Guyana, Jamaica, Mexico, Thailand, Trinidad and Tobago, and Venezuela. In Mexico, the licensing requirement for many items was to be maintained for a spe- cific period only. Sierra Leone added to the list of goods requiring specific licenses. On Decem- ber 31, 1970, Honduras revised the import tariffs which henceforth will apply also to imports from the other participants in the Central American Common Market, which were previously exempt from all import duties. At the same time Hon- duras repealed the 30 per cent import surcharge adopted under the Protocol of San Jose. Subse- quently, the other Central American countries, maintaining commercial relations with Honduras, required a guarantee on Honduran products equivalent to the duties applicable to imports from the rest of the world. Import discrimination through quantitative re- strictions appears, on balance, to have been fur- ther reduced. This is due primarily to (a) formal abolition in Western European countries of re- strictions on commodities of CMEA origin, and (b) the progressive termination of bilateral trade and payments arrangements. A number of coun- tries, including the Bahamas, Ivory Coast, Kuwait, Niger, Rwanda, and Uganda, ceased to invoke Article XXXV of the GATT in respect of Japan. Austria freed from quantitative restrictions a sig- nificant number of commodities of Japanese origin. Important developments with respect to import taxation included the announcement by the United Kingdom in October 1970 of the substitu- tion of import levies for the present system of agricultural subsidies. Algeria in January 1971 announced the abolition of tariff preferences for nonessential consumer goods of French origin. Restrictions on Current Invisibles As noted in the previous Report, the United Kingdom at the beginning of 1970 lifted the re- striction on travel allowances which it had intro- duced in 1966. France increased its exchange allocation for tourist travel twice in 1970 but did not fully lift its restriction. Certain of the Opera- tions Account countries also relaxed their travel restrictions. Early in 1971 France further in- creased its exchange allocation for tourist al- lowances. Ecuador abolished all restrictions on payments and transfers for current payments, including those relating to travel, when it estab- lished a new par value and accepted the obliga- tions of Article VIII. Japan, which had ceased to restrict travel exchange in 1969, increased fu r- ther the automatic allocations which authorized banks may make available without license from the Bank of Japan. El Salvador raised the travel allocations and reduced the amount of guarantee deposit to be made by intending travelers, while Guatemala increased the exchange allowances for tourist and business travel, abolished the 100 per cent guarantee deposit, and relaxed restrictions on certain other current invisibles. Iceland raised the automatic allowance for tourist travel as well as certain special allowances for travel agencies. India also relaxed restrictions on foreign travel. Morocco increased the exchange allowances for 3 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution REPORT ON EXCHANGE RESTRICTIONS business travel and also raised somewhat the al- lowance for tourist travel. Many developing countries and some others found it necessary to maintain or tighten existing restrictions on travel exchange. The Dominican Republic continued a zero allocation for tourist purposes, and an intensification of restrictions took place in Algeria, Chile, Greece, Israel, Nigeria, Peru, and Uruguay. A number of countries revised their exchange control regulations affecting domestic or foreign banknotes, often in connection with those con- cerning travel exchange. France resumed the practice of redeeming domestic banknotes pre- sented by banks abroad, provided they were mailed direct to the head office of the Bank of France. The Operations Account countries gen- erally took similar measures. Both France and the United Kingdom raised the limits on the amounts of domestic and foreign banknotes that may be exported by travelers, and China doubled the foreign currency that travelers may take out. Malaysia and Singapore doubled the amount of domestic currency that travelers may take out or bring in. Italy restricted the crediting of lire bank- notes presented for credit to convertible nonresi- dent accounts to those notes that were mailed by banks abroad direct to the head office of the Bank of Italy, and Sweden made the repurchase from banks abroad of large-denomination bank- notes (SKr 10,000 notes) subject to prior ap- proval by the central bank. Several developing countries imposed severe restrictions on the im- port and export of domestic banknotes. Malawi instructed the local banks to refuse acceptance of domestic banknotes offered by banks abroad, Kenya ceased redeeming domestic banknotes offered by banks abroad, Tanzania and Uganda prohibited the import and export of domestic currency and ceased redeeming domestic bank- notes offered by banks abroad, and the Sudan prohibited the import and export of domestic banknotes. Peru imposed restrictions on the im- port and export of national currency. With respect to current invisibles other than travel expenditures, the following are some of the developments. Zambia lifted its restriction on the transfer of profits and dividends. The Philippines, following its exchange reform in February 1970, relaxed restrictions on the making of payments for most current invisibles. Guatemala, in addi- 4 tion to relaxing restrictions on tourist and busi- ness travel, relaxed those on family remittances and remittances for student expenditures. On the other hand, Chile reduced the allowances for family remittances, insurance premiums, and some other current items. Argentina late in 1970 for a few days suspended all exchange transac- tions, then gradually permitted various types of current and capital payments, and by the end of the year no longer maintained any restrictions on current payments. Arrears on the transfer of current payments, often consisting largely of arrears on import pay- ments, continue to exist in several member coun- tries. These include the Dominican Republic, Ghana, Nigeria, and the Syrian Arab Republic. Haiti, Paraguay, the Philippines, and Turkey cleared their arrears on current payments. Nigeria in April 1970 partially cleared its arrears on non- import current payments, but arrears on import payments increased sharply. Multiple Currency Practices Major exchange reforms took place in Ecua- dor, Indonesia, the Philippines, Turkey, and Viet- Nam. Most of these reforms resulted in a clear improvement of the exchange system, and those in Ecuador and Turkey involved the establish- ment of new par values. China established an initial par value shortly after eliminating its minor multiple currency practice. Venezuela eliminated its exchange subsidies on exports of coffee and cocoa and on imports of wheat and powdered milk. The major reforms referred to above included the following features. The Philippines introduced a multiple currency practice when it established a fluctuating free market rate and prescribed the surrender at the par value of 80 per cent of the proceeds from four leading export commodities. Subsequently the surrender at the par value re- quirement was replaced by exchange taxes (sta- bilization taxes) on exports. Indonesia eliminated its "overprice" arrangement and merged its two ex- change markets, the BE and DP markets,4 at the 4 The BE (Bonus Export) market included payments for imports classified as essential and semiessential and certain other services and receipts from a major part of exports. All other transactions took place in the second- ary DP (Complementary Exchange) market. Under the dual market system a complicated multiple exchange rate system was in effect. In addition to the two basic ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MAIN DEVELOPMENTS IN RESTRICTIVE PRACTICES level of the DP market but maintained a separate, more appreciated exchange rate (the closing BE rate) for imports financed with foreign aid; late in 1970 the aid rate also was eliminated, and only one multiple currency practice remained, result- ing from an exchange tax on exports. Ecuador's exchange reform involved the unification of the two exchange markets, the abolition of all mul- tiple currency practices, and the establishment of a new par value; as noted above, the country then accepted the obligations of Article VIII. Viet- Nam introduced a parallel exchange market with a fixed exchange rate of VN$275 per U.S. dollar for most transactions. Turkey established a new par value for its currency at a more depreciated level (devaluing from LT 9 to LT 15 per U.S. dollar) and at the same time effectively eliminated the existing multiple exchange rates. As part of the reform, however, Turkey introduced a less depre- ciated buying rate of LT 12 per U.S. dollar to be applied to the export proceeds of certain tradi- tional agricultural commodities. The exchange profits resulting from the purchase of export pro- ceeds derived from the sales of these commodities were channeled into an Exchange Equalization Fund for the financing of investment in export- oriented projects. Among countries operating a flexible exchange rate policy and maintaining multiple currency practices, Brazil and Colombia continued to de- preciate their currencies from time to time, taking account of the rate of domestic inflation and other criteria. Chile followed a similar policy until July 1970. In the Philippines the peso depreciated, after the reform early in the year, until late Sep- tember when its rate was stabilized in the market. Korea, the other country with a flexible rate policy, does not have multiple currency practices; adjustments in the rate of the won in 1970 were not substantial. Peru maintained its dual market system but pegged the previously fluctuating rate in the draft market. Bolivia eliminated a multiple currency practice resulting from deposit requirements for export proceeds. Ceylon reclassified some import exchange rates, the BE and DP rates, a number of implicit exchange rates arose from an export surrender price scheme (overprice scheme) under which exporters were required to surrender varying portions of export proceeds at the BE rate, while the remainder could be retained for sale at the more depreciated DP rate. commodities, bringing about a widening of the scope of the certificate market. Chile made certain changes in the exchange taxes applicable to the brokers' market. Pakistan again extended its bonus system to additional categories of foreign exchange earnings (mainly by granting a 10 per cent bonus on major traditional exports that had been sold at the official rate since the inception of the bonus scheme in 1959, and a 45 per cent bonus on exchange received from foreign tour- ists), and, through this system, further raised the effective cost of imports. Brazil again suspended the exchange tax on cocoa exports for a specified quantity of sales. The operation of the special exchange market in France did not undergo any significant change, but in the United Kingdom the property currency market was closed and transactions previously channeled through it were henceforth settled in the investment currency market. The operation of the latter was affected by a number of changes in administrative approval practices, outstanding among which was the wider permission granted late in 1970 to borrow non-Sterling Area cur- rency for portfolio investment in "foreign cur- rency securities" (see section on Measures Affect- ing Capital, below). There were no major changes in the operation of the free exchange market in the Belgian-Luxembourg Economic Union. Import Deposits, Import Surcharges, and Measures to Stimulate Exports For many member countries an assessment of the restrictiveness of the import regime requires consideration of the effects of changes in advance deposit requirements, import surcharges, etc. Cases in point are Israel, Spain, Turkey, and Yugoslavia, where these factors may have been as important as changes in formal liberalization. Another complicating factor, one that is increas- ing in importance, is state trading, which tends to obscure the purchasing policies followed with respect to nature, volume, price, quality, and origin of imports. A number of developing coun- tries brought additional import commodities under the control of the government or of state-man- aged agencies. They included Algeria, Ceylon, Guyana, India, Iraq, Malawi, Somalia, Tanzania, Uganda, and Zambia. 5 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution REPORT ON EXCHANGE RESTRICTIONS Advance Import Deposits The United Kingdom, having reduced the rate of deposit in several steps from 50 per cent to 20 per cent, terminated its import deposit scheme on December 4, 1970, two years after its introduc- tion. Japan on May 18, 1970 suspended the ap- plication of advance deposits by reducing the rate from 1 per cent to zero per cent. In March 1970 Spain permitted advance deposits to be financed by the foreign suppliers, and as from January 1, 1971 the requirement was reduced from 20 per cent to 10 per cent and extended until June 30, 1971, although the scheme had been scheduled to expire on December 31, 1970. Israel introduced an advance deposit scheme applicable mainly to private sector imports of goods subject to a cus- toms duty of 30 per cent or more, representing some 16 per cent of total commodity imports in 1969-70. Banks were requested not to increase advances to importers for the purpose of financ- ing the deposits. At the beginning of 1971, the deposit rate was reduced from 50 per cent to 40 per cent of the c.i.f. value. The Dominican Republic, Ethiopia, Morocco, and Somalia abolished their advance deposit re- quirements during 1970. In Ecuador, after the prior import deposit rates were raised in March- April 1970, the Government announced in August that these rates would be reduced quar- terly in accordance with a program designed to lead to the elimination of advance deposit re- quirements on List I imports (approximately 75 per cent of total imports in 1969-70) by June 30, 1971 and on List II imports by September 30, 1972. Korea made the application of its advance deposit requirements nondiscriminatory; previ- ously, they had affected Japanese suppliers more than those in more distant countries. Colombia reduced the rates of advance import deposits gradually but substantially. Many rates were re- duced from 130 per cent to a range of 30 to 1 per cent or from 70 per cent to 30 per cent; also the advance deposit requirement equivalent to 95 per cent of the foreign currency needed for import payments was eliminated for import payments made within 30 days of shipment. Chile continued the process of exempting most import commod- ities from advance deposit and of reducing the coverage of the 10,000 per cent rate which had served as a de facto prohibition on private sector imports of the items concerned; by August 3, 6 1970 all advance deposits other than the 10,000 per cent rate had been abolished. Viet-Nam in September 1970 reintroduced advance import deposit requirements and in October increased their commodity coverage; some of the rates were lower for specified imports under U.S. and French aid. In October 1970, Yugoslavia intro- duced a 50 per cent advance import deposit that was additional to a requirement in force since late 1967 prescribing that the full dinar counter- value must be deposited prior to the making of the import payment. The rate of the new deposit requirement was reduced in December 1970 and January 1971, and it was eliminated on Janu- ary 24, 1971. As part of the exchange reform of February 21, 1970 the Philippines abolished the cash margin deposit requirements on the opening of import letters of credit ("special time de- posits"). However, in July the commercial banks adopted a uniform 30 per cent cash margin re- quirement on the opening of import letters of credit which was subsequently increased to a uni- form rate of 50 per cent. Turkey halved its guar- antee deposit rates when it changed its par value and made further reductions in January 1971. Import Surcharges Costa Rica on September 1, 1970 introduced the 30 per cent surcharge provided for by the Protocol of San Jose, the last member of the Cen- tral American Common Market to do so. In May 1970 Ecuador raised the stabilization surcharges from 11 per cent to 20 per cent on List I imports and from 22 per cent to 38-55 per cent on List II imports. In July the surcharges on List II im- ports were reduced to 20-30 per cent and in August all surcharges were eliminated. Nigeria reduced its import surcharge from IVz per cent to 5 per cent in April 1970. Turkey reduced the stamp duty on imports from 25 per cent to 10 per cent when it established a new par value. Uruguay on October 21, 1970 announced an increase of 5 percentage points in the surcharge on most commodities. Ghana's budget provided for the imposition of a temporary surcharge at rates ranging from 5 per cent to 100 per cent, in conjunction with the freeing of a wide range of imports from adminis- trative controls; some of the rates introduced, however, went beyond 100 per cent. Israel in August 1970 applied a temporary sur- ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MAIN DEVELOPMENTS IN RESTR ICT IVE PRACTICES charge of 20 per cent of the c.i.f. value to vir- tually all imported commodities; it was scheduled to expire on December 31, 1970 but was ex- tended to March 31, 1972. Paraguay eliminated the exemption from import surcharges for con- sumer goods and introduced a sales tax on im- ports. In July 1970 Yugoslavia introduced a tem- porary import surcharge of 5 per cent on the c.i.f. value, but all duty-free commodities (ma in ly raw materials) remained exempt, and in Janua ry 1971 the 5 per cent surcharge was reduced to 2 per cent. Export Incentives and Export Taxes In France, the preferential rediscount rate for medium-term export credits was abolished for sales to EEC countries but maintained for sales to other countries outside the French Franc Area. Effective July 1, 1971 the interest rate on export credit will be adjusted to the levels in force in other industrial countries, and the cover available will be raised from 80-90 per cent to 100 per cent. In October 1970 France created special facilities for certain exporters selling to the United States and Canada. In Japan, the cen- tral bank raised its interest rates on export finance by about 1 per cent per annum; these rates have since been kept unchanged, although the Bank of Japan's official discount rate was lowered twice during the past six months. In October 1970, with the agreement of the U.K. authorities, the clearing and Scottish banks in- creased the special fixed rate of interest on all new commitments under medium-term and long- term loans for export and shipbuilding finance to 7 per cent; this rate had been unchanged at 5l/2 per cent since 1962. Furthermore, the rate at which commercial banks made short-term export finance available under direct guarantee from the Export Credit Guarantee Department (ECGD) was raised at the same time from bank rate to l/2 per cent over bank rate. In April the ECGD's permissible liabilities were raised from <£3.9 bil- lion to .£6.5 billion. Austria also raised the over- all ceiling on export credit insurance greatly. In the United States, the Export-Import Bank late in October 1970 relaxed its requirements for approv- ing export-financing loans to U.S. commercial banks. In the Netherlands, the first "frame-work agreement" concerning export credit was con- cluded, the pa r tner coun try being Iran. Spain in September 1970 allowed the commercial banks more leeway in granting export credit. In Iran, the central bank in May 1970 reduced the interest rate charged to the commercial banks on f u n ds used for the gran t ing of export credit. Many measures were taken in the field of direct export incentives. Brazil applies a large number of fiscal incentives to exports, principally of manu- factured commodities. These incentives now include exemptions not only from indirect but also direct taxes, as well as a subsidy in the form of a tax credit against the indus tr ial product tax on do- mestic sales. Paraguay also granted tax exemp- tions on exports. At the time of the devaluation Turkey simplified its tax rebate system. Ghana introduced an export bonus system intended to encourage nontraditional exports. In September 1970 the Philippines enacted an export incentives law providing for exemptions f rom cer ta in taxes including the export tax. As noted under Multiple Currency Practices above, an exchange tax on exports was introduced in 1970 to replace the 80:20 mixing arrangement. Argentina broadened the scope of export finance facilities for "promoted exports." Pakistan for the first time since the in- ception of the export bonus scheme accorded a bonus on basic t rad i t ional exports and also, on Ju ly 21, 1970, granted a 45 per cent bonus on exports of sugar. Ecuador in August 1970 granted subsidies ranging from 2 per cent to 7 per cent based on the f.o.b. value to a few exports. The Syrian Arab Republic created a Development Fund for Industrial Exports. Colom- bia reduced the term of tax credit certificates under its export bonus scheme from 12 months to 9 months to increase the incentive to minor ex- ports. Ecuador in July 1970 imposed taxes of 7 per cent and 15 per cent on the f.o.b. export value of bananas and minor exports, respectively, but shortly thereafter these tax rates were reduced to 3 per cent and 7 per cent. In August, in the context of the devaluation of the sucre, export taxation was extended to most exports with three tax rates of 5 per cent, 10 per cent, and 15 per cent. China eliminated the export surcharge on certain agricultural exports from July 1, 1970. Thailand granted special rebates corresponding to 25 per cent of the applicable rice export premium ( t ax) on most exports of rice in large quantities. Malaysia on February 2, 1970 introduced a sur- 7 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution REPORT ON EXCHANGE RESTRICTIONS tax on exports of rubber, which came in addition to the regular export tax but was applicable only when the export price exceeded M$0.60 a pound. Ivory Coast in 1970 raised existing export taxes to tax away part of the windfall profits resulting from the 1969 devaluation. Other changes in export controls included the following: the United Kingdom simplified the ex- change control formalities for exports, and France first raised the amount beyond which export transactions must be registered with an authorized bank and later raised this amount again and ap- plied the same relaxation to imports. The United States relaxed its export controls in East-West trade by liberalizing 222 product categories. Greece simplified administrative procedures by transferring to the Bank of Greece the power to issue permits for the export of a wide range of products. The surrender requirements for export pro- ceeds were tightened in Algeria and Nigeria. Bilateral Payments Arrangements In 1970, Fund members made further progress in terminating their remaining bilateral payments agreements. Some 22 payments agreements were terminated in the period end-1969 through Jan- uary 1971, of which 11 were agreements with nonmembers. In some cases, furthermore, agree- ment was reached to abolish specified bilateral payments arrangements in the near future. The number of payments agreements between Fund members has now been reduced to some 50, and several of these are inoperative, but the number of agreements between members and nonmembers still is well over 200. Progress was especially marked in Austria, Ghana, Mali, Uruguay, and Yugoslavia. Noteworthy was the termination of payments agreements with the U.S.S.R. by Aus- tria, Lebanon, and Nepal. Finland decided to continue settlements with Czechoslovakia and Poland on a convertible currency basis during 1971, although the payments agreements with these countries have not formally expired. Member countries utilizing clearing arrange- ments continued to experience difficulties in op- erating them. Some again found it necessary to sell excess clearing balances to third parties, often at a substantial discount, or to increase swing credits significantly. 8 Measures Affecting Capital In the industrialized countries many changes in capital controls took place; on balance there was a minor relaxation of the curbs on capital outflows. The United States maintained its direct invest- ment controls and its foreign credit restraints, al- though making both more flexible, retained the Interest Equalization Tax, and raised the mar- ginal reserve requirement on Euro-dollar borrow- ings from 10 per cent to 20 per cent. Relaxation measures introduced at the beginning of 1970 under the direct investment program included in- creased transferability between different groups of countries of earnings allowable for reinvestment abroad, permission to use short-term borrowing abroad as an offset to foreign direct investment, the elimination of the US$250,000 minimum for the export term-loan ceiling, and the introduction of special allowances for the financing of exports to affiliates and for capitalized expenditures for exploration. The United Kingdom maintained the voluntary program of restraint on exports of capital to the more developed countries of the Sterling Area and the mandatory restrictions on direct investment outside the Sterling Area. How- ever, the United Kingdom first formalized and liberalized controls over foreign currency invest- ment in offshore funds by institutional investors and then liberalized the rules for the borrowing of non-Sterling Area currency by residents for the purpose of purchasing "foreign currency secu- rities"; as a result, the investment currency pre- mium declined sharply beginning in December. The United Kingdom also merged the property currency market into the investment currency market (August 19, 1970), thus making the pur- chase by residents of personal real estate outside the Sterling Area considerably less expensive. The exchange rate for investment currency ended the year at a premium of about 24 per cent over the official rate and subsequently declined to 16 per cent. Early in 1971 the United Kingdom took measures to restrict residents from borrowing in the Euro-dollar market for conversion into pounds, but the restrictions on direct investment outside the Sterling Area by U.K. residents were eased. France relaxed its restrictions on direct investment outside the French Franc Area, in- creased somewhat its approvals of inward direct investment, and introduced an insurance scheme essentially for new direct investment in the Op- ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MAIN DEVELOPMENTS IN RESTRICTIVE PRACTICES erations Account countries. France also intro- duced special controls over real estate operations by nonresidents in France, and, with a view to influencing the Euro-franc market more closely, fur ther reduced the scope of the exemptions from prior approval for borrowing abroad. The ceilings imposed on the net foreign currency position of the authorized banks, which had required them to contribute about US$150 million to the central reserves in 1969, were lifted altogether in 1970, after the mandatory dollar deposits had been reduced as an intermediate step. At the end of the year, the exchange rate for devises-titre was around F 6 per U.S. dollar, implying a premium of close to 10 per cent on the par value. Japan relaxed restrictions on inward and outward direct investment and on portfolio investment by resi- dents in foreign securities, provided the investment took place through the intermediary of securities investment trusts, and allowed life and nonlife insurance companies to invest in foreign securities, subject to an overall ceiling. Japan also dis- couraged long-term borrowing abroad and fu r ther encouraged a "yen shift" in import financing. The Netherlands allowed a number of placings of Euro-guilder notes, under a queue system and subject to the terms of these issues being com- parable to those for domestic issues and to the entire issue being sold to nonresidents other than U.S. citizens or U.S. residents. Also, in April 1970 the restrictions on the net foreign asset posi- tion of the authorized banks were lifted. Foreign issues in Germany and Switzerland remained sub- ject to informal rationing but were at relatively high levels; early in 1970, the Swiss market was closed for two months to foreign borrowers. The German Bundesbank reintroduced differential marginal reserve requirements on additions to banks' foreign liabilities. Furthermore, the Bundes- bank decided to sell money market paper to German commercial banks only under the condi- tion not to re-sell it to nonresidents nor to give it en pension abroad under repurchase agreements. In addition, the Bundesbank, by certain minimum reserve measures, discouraged the banks from taking up credit abroad in deutsche mark for onlending in any currency to customers abroad and it also took some additional measures to dis- courage borrowing abroad by banks. Difficulty in obtaining funds in the international bond market, which narrowed considerably in 1970, led many borrowers to secure medium-term Euro-currency bank credits. Italy on October 1, 1970 restricted residents' purchases of shares of foreign financial institutions to those listed on at least three foreign stock exchanges "of prime importance," but later dropped this special requirement. China issued a policy statement on the facilities available to inward direct investments; screening would be geared more closely to the desired in- dustrialization objectives. Indonesia after the ex- change reform freed the negotiation of rupiah securities and foreign currency securities between residents and nonresidents, as well as the import and export of such securities. Ecuador and Peru, when introducing comprehensive reforms of their exchange system, abolished the freedom for resi- dent-owned capital to move abroad, and both took steps to obtain the repatriation or surrender of resident-owned assets held abroad. The Philip- pines adopted a law setting ceilings on govern- ment borrowing abroad and government guaran- tees for private foreign borrowings. Under this law the central bank may not approve new foreign borrowings that would increase the country's total debt service burden above 20 per cent of the average foreign exchange earnings of the previous three years. Argentina, when resuming exchange transactions late in 1970 after the temporary suspension, did not restore the previous freedom for outward movements of resident-owned capital. A number of developing countries imposed or tightened restrictions on local borrowings by non- resident-controlled companies. They included Malawi and Trinidad and Tobago. Jamaica and Venezuela, which had imposed such restrictions in 1969, maintained them in 1970. Singapore, in an effort to facilitate the opera- tion of its Asian dollar market, introduced a sys- tem of numbered accounts for non-Sterling Area residents. The Philippines several months after the exchange reform took a similar step and on July 21, 1970 permitted designated banks to accept deposits in foreign currencies under a numbered accounts system. The interest rate on these de- posits was payable in foreign exchange and ex- empt from the existing interest ceilings, and the Government guaranteed that there would be no restrictions on the withdrawal or outward transfer of the deposits. The scheme was designed pri- marily to stimulate the repatriation of resident- owned capital. The Syrian Arab Republic intro- 9 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution REPORT ON EXCHANGE RESTRICTIONS duced additional facilities for the opening of foreign currency accounts by residents and non- residents, and Iraq took similar measures. Two Sterling Area countries, Malta and Trini- dad and Tobago, extended exchange control to the rest of the Sterling Area and in doing so imposed restrictions on certain capital transac- tions. Uganda, for capital control reasons, ex- tended exchange control to Kenya and Tanzania, and early in 1971 Tanzania extended exchange control to Kenya and Uganda for similar reasons. Gold Changes in regulations were relatively minor. Indonesia abolished the requirement of an import license issued by the Ministry of Trade. France and certain Operations Account countries facil- itated the import by travelers of articles containing a minor quantity of gold, but France brought gold medals under the general controls over import and export of gold. Early in 1971, the U.K. restric- tions on dealings in gold coins and the use of the metal for manufacturing medals, etc., were re- laxed. China lifted certain controls over the im- port of gold. III. Regional Arrangements On June 30, 1970 Denmark, Ireland, Norway, and the United Kingdom began negotiations with a view to full membership in the European Eco- nomic Community (EEC). Talks on other ar- rangements began with Austria, Sweden, and Switzerland on November 11, and with Finland, Iceland, and Portugal on November 24. Negotia- tions for a nonpreferential trade agreement with Japan began on September 17. Negotiations were begun by the United Arab Republic and Lebanon on September 24, and September 30, respectively, to enter into preferential trade agreements with the EEC. On January 20, 1971, Argentina began negotiations for a nonpreferential trade agreement and on March 2, 1971, Cyprus began exploratory talks for a possible agreement with the EEC. The second Yaounde Convention signed on July 29, 1969 came into force on January 1, 1971 for five years. The new Convention renewed the associate status of the existing participants.5 On 5 Burundi, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Chad, Democratic Republic of Congo, People's Republic of the Congo, Dahomey, Gabon, Ivory Coast, Malagasy Repub- lic, Mali, Mauritania, Niger, Rwanda, Senegal, Somalia, Togo, and Upper Volta. 10 the same day, the second association agreement signed at Arusha on September 24, 1969 also came into force, linking the EEC with Kenya, Tanzania, and Uganda until January 31, 1975. On March 19, 1970 a nonpreferential trade agreement was signed with Yugoslavia for a period of three years beginning May 1. This was the first negotiation concluded by the Community since the common commercial policy was put into effect at the end of the transitional period on January 1, 1970. Agreements were reached with India and with Pakistan in mid-1970 for the pref- erential entry of such products as jute, textiles, silks, and handicrafts into the EEC. Preferential trade agreements were signed with Israel and Spain on June 29, 1970 and went into force on October 1. On November 23, 1970 a protocol was signed providing for passage from the preparatory to the transitional stage in the Turkey-EEC asso- ciation existing since September 12, 1963. On December 5, 1970 a preferential trade agreement was concluded with Malta aimed at completing a Malta-EEC customs union within ten years from April 1, 1971. At its meeting of May 25-26, 1970, the Coun- cil of the EEC approved two important regula- tions further implementing the common commer- cial policy. One established a common system for imports from "third" countries that either are GATT members or are treated as GATT coun- tries and the other set up a common procedure for administering quantitative import and export quotas in trade with nonmember countries. They superseded the three interim regulations of De- cember 10, 1968, which constituted the first step toward a common commercial policy. The first regulation covers trade with all GATT members and assimilated countries and establishes a new, increased liberalization list, bound at Community level and covering 898 of the 1,097 full headings in the common customs tariff, while the 1968 list covered 824 headings. In September 1970 this common liberalization list for the GATT countries was further expanded. Imports from state trading countries remained covered by a regulation of December 19, 1969, the commodity list of which was expanded in mid-1970. The May 1970 Coun- cil meeting also empowered the Commission to conduct negotiations and consultations with GATT countries without asking the Council's permission in each case. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution REGIONAL ARRANGEMENTS At The Hague in December 1969 the Commu- nity members' heads of state or government agreed that a plan in stages should be worked out during 1970 with a view to the creation of an economic and monetary union. On February 9, 1971, the Council of the EEC decided to move by stages toward such a union. The aim is to com- plete the whole process of economic and monetary union by the end of 1980, with the first stage due for completion by the end of 1973. Monetary cooperation will in part rest on a mechanism of mutual assistance. A system of short-term monetary support has already been in existence since early 1970 with quotas in a total amount of US$1 billion, while another US$1 billion can be made available if the need arises. The same quota shares apply to the new medium- term monetary support system in an overall amount of 2 billion units of account, which will become operational from January 1, 1972 for an initial period of four years and then will be auto- matically renewable every five years. Once the new scheme becomes effective, member states will have to consult their EEC partners before seeking medium-term assistance outside the Community. Normally, the interest rate will be halfway be- tween the International Monetary Fund's rate and the current market rate. In the first three years, credit will be granted for a maximum of two to three years, but after that the period will be two to five years. Although the transition and the final stages of monetary union remain to be determined, the aim is that by the end of the decade the relative par values of EEC currencies will be irrevocably fixed. However, if the member countries do not reach agreement on further progress by the end of 1973, or if one or more of the member countries feel that progress has not been parallel in the economic and monetary fields, then there will be an extended period of two years during which the necessary adjustments may be made. If the ad- justments are not made within this extended period, the measures already taken toward a monetary union will be automatically inoperative from the end of 1975. The membership of the European Free Trade Association (EFTA) 6 was expanded when Ice- 6 The present members are Austria, Denmark, Iceland, Norway, Portugal, Sweden, Switzerland, and the United Kingdom. Within EFTA, an examination of nontariff barriers was con- tinued; two new agreements to abolish such meas- ures took effect on January 1, 1971, and both are open to participation by other countries. The customs territories of the member countries of Benelux (Belgium, the Netherlands, and Lux- embourg) were unified on February 1, 1971; this unification does not preclude the maintenance of formalities prescribed by national legislation in matters of excise tax, turnover tax, and similar taxes. At their meeting in Kabul in December 1970, the Council of Ministers for Asian Economic Co- operation adopted the "Kabul Declaration" calling for new steps in trade and monetary cooperation. A preparatory committee of interested ECAFE member countries was set up to fur ther examine the proposal for an Asian Clearing Union and to negotiate an agreement on the terms and condi- tions of such a Union, and intergovernmental committees were established to fu r ther examine proposals for a Trade Expansion Program and an Asian Reserve Bank. In the Caribbean Free Trade Association (CARIFTA)/ the Council of Ministers approved the membership application of British Honduras. The East Caribbean Currency Authority joined the regional settlements agreement between the central banks of Guyana, Jamaica, and Trinidad and Tobago. In the East African Community, Uganda ex- tended exchange control to Kenya and Tanzania, and early in 1971 Tanzania extended exchange control to Kenya and Uganda for the purpose of restricting capital outflows only. The member countries of the West African Customs Union (UDEAO) 8 in May 1970 adopted a protocol creating a West African Economic Community (CEAO) open for accession by other African countries. Togo attended in the capacity of observer. The CEAO would have as its aims improvements in infrastructure, transpor- tation, and communications, the promotion of an accelerated and more integrated industrialization policy in the member countries, and the promotion of a higher level of intraregional trade. Not for Redistribution Explanatory Note to Country Surveys In Part II, individual surveys of the exchange systems of the member countries of the Fund, including three nonmetropolitan territories, are given. The exchange system of one other coun- try which was not a member of the Fund at the time this Report was written is also described. In general, the surveys relate to the exchange systems as at the end of 1970. For a few countries the surveys relate to the exchange systems at a later date or include references to significant developments which took place early in 1971. The description of an exchange system is not necessarily confined to those aspects involving exchange restrictions or exchange controls. As in previous Reports, questions of definition and juris- diction have not been raised, and an attempt has been made to describe restrictive systems in their entirety, except for the tariff structure and, in most cases, direct taxes on exports and imports. Thus, the surveys include references to such features as import licensing, advance deposit requirements, import surcharges, travel taxes, export licensing, and export incentive schemes. Similarly, the sec- tion "Changes during 1970" may include refer- ences to certain developments that have a direct impact on international transactions but are not reflected in the body of the survey, such as major revisions of import tariffs or developments relating to regional cooperation. A standardized framework has been employed in drafting the surveys: each system is described under similar headings, and each country survey contains a final section that lists chronologically the more significant changes which took place in the restrictive system during 1970 and, for a few countries, at the beginning of 1971. An indication of the subject matter to be found under these headings is given in the following paragraphs. Under Exchange Rate System, the par value, where one has been agreed with the Fund, and/or the official exchange rates are given, the latter usually in terms of the U.S. dollar, together with a reference to other rates which may be essential to the country's exchange rate system. In the sur- veys of certain countries with multiple exchange rate systems, further details are given in the Table of Exchange Rates (see below). The rates quoted are those effective on December 31, 1970, unless stated otherwise. Under Exchange Control Territory, the extent of applicability of the exchange control is ex- plained when it covers two or more sovereign or autonomous territories whose residents have com- mon rights and obligations under the exchange control regulations. Under Administration of Control, some indica- tion is given of the authorities responsible for policy and administration of the controls and of the extent to which their powers are delegated for practical working purposes. Under Prescription of Currency, the require- ments affecting the selection of the currency and method of settlement for transactions with other countries are described. Where a country has concluded payments agreements with other coun- tries or monetary areas, the terms of these agree- ments often lead to prescription of the currency for specified categories of payments to and from the countries concerned. The countries with which bilateral payments agreements are in force are listed either in the text or in a footnote. For a country whose currency has international impor- tance, the prescription of currency arrangements involve the use of its own currency held by non- residents in accounts with authorized banks. Pay- ments to and from such nonresident accounts are then regarded as equivalent to settlements in for- eign currency. Under Nonresident Accounts, an indication is given of the manner in which the country regards the accounts in its currency of account holders not regarded as resident in that country, and the facilities and limitations attached to such accounts. Where there is more than one type of nonresident account, the nature and operation of the various types are described. Under Imports and Import Payments, import licensing requirements are described briefly, and details are given of the additional requirements imposed on payments for imports and of any advance deposit requirements. The term "open general license," which is used in some countries, indicates arrangements whereby certain imports or other international transactions are exempt from the restrictive application of licensing re- quirements, in contrast to an "individual license," which may be either given freely, or restricted in its issue, according to administrative decisions. 15 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution REPORT ON EXCHANGE RESTRICTIONS The expression "global quota" is employed in the sense that many countries now use it, to indicate quotas that are not necessarily universal in their application but instead may apply to a group of countries, e.g., global quotas for imports from countries in the European Economic Community. Under Payments for Invisibles, action in the matter of permitting payments abroad for current transactions in invisibles is described briefly, together with any limitations on the export of foreign and domestic banknotes. For some coun- tries that do not impose limitations on payments for invisibles, this section is combined with the section on Proceeds from Invisibles (see below). Under Exports and Export Proceeds, the appli- cation of export licensing, where this is operative, is indicated, together with a brief outline of the requirements imposed on the proceeds derived from exports. The expression "exchange receipts must be surrendered" is used to indicate that the recipient is required by the regulations to sell his foreign exchange against local currency, usually at the official rate, to the central bank or to a com- mercial bank or exchange dealer authorized for this purpose. In some countries there is a require- ment that the exchange be sold in a free market. Under Proceeds from Invisibles, any conditions governing exchange derived from transactions in invisibles are given, and any limitations on the import of foreign and domestic banknotes are described. Under Capital, a general indication of the spe- cial arrangements or limitations attached to inter- national receipts and payments in respect of capi- tal items is given. Where special arrangements for foreign capital also cover the income thereon, they are dealt with in this section rather than in the sections on Payments for Invisibles and Pro- ceeds from Invisibles. Under Gold, the principal provisions are sum- marized that govern the holding, negotiation, and import and export of gold coins and gold in other forms. In the Table of Exchange Rates, which is pro- vided for certain countries having a multiple cur- rency practice involving more than two rate levels, the exchange rates effective on a specified date are given. For convenience, the data in these tables are in terms of local currency units per U.S. dollar. The tables include effective rates arising from the negotiation of percentages of the total exchange at different rates, the imposition of exchange taxes, the negotiation of exchange certificates, etc. Under Changes during 1970, the more signifi- cant changes in the country's restrictive system during 1970 are presented in chronological order. Important measures made effective in the early months of 1971 are indicated at the end of certain surveys or in footnotes to the text. * * * The individual country surveys were prepared by the staff of the Fund and reviewed by the authorities of the countries concerned. Prepara- tion of this part of the Report was under the general direction of Mr. J.H.C. de Looper, Ad- visor, Exchange and Trade Relations Department. 16 ©International Monetary Fund. Exchange subsidies are applied to the official buying rate as follows: Af 3.12 per US$1 for export proceeds from cotton when payment is received under a bilateral payments agreement; Af 10 per US$1 for proceeds in convertible currencies from exports of wool; Af 25 per US$1 for proceeds in convertible cur- rencies from exports of cotton; and A f 20 per US$1 for proceeds from exports of karakul. All other transactions take place at free market rates through either the banks or the bazaar; proceeds from the export of wa lnu ts received over bilateral payments accounts are subject to an exchange tax of 9.5 per cent. The A fghan i s tan Bank maintains its operational free market selling rate for the U. S. dollar within Af 2.0 per US$1 of the daily free market rate quoted in the bazaar. On December 31, 1970, the free market rate of the A fghan is tan Bank was Af 86.50 buying, and Af 87.00 selling, per US$1, and the free market rate in the bazaar was Af 89.75 buying, and Af 90.25 selling, per US$1. The Afghanistan Bank also posts free market rates for deutsche mark, French francs, pounds sterling, and Swiss francs, which are set by applying their par va lues to the current free market rate for the U. S. dollar, and free market rates for the Indian rupee and Pak is tan rupee that are determined by demand and supply for the currencies concerned. Administration of Control Foreign exchange is controlled by the Government through the Afghanistan Bank. The control is facili- tated by the existence of relatively large companies, some of them government owned or government con- trolled, specializing in the export of such commodities as karakul, cotton, wool, and carpets. However, these companies do not exercise a monopoly over the export of such commodities. Prescription of Currency Settlements with countries with which Afghanistan has bilateral payments agreements l must be made in the foreign currencies specified in the agreements. The proceeds from exports of karakul, wool, and cotton to other countries must be obtained in convertible curren- cies. There are no other prescription of currency requirements. Imports and Import Payments Imports are not subject to license. Imports of a few items (e.g., some drugs, liquor, arms, and ammunition) are prohibited on public policy grounds or for security reasons; in some instances, however, special permission to import these goods may be granted. The importation of certain other goods (e.g., a few textiles, agricultural and food products, and selected nonessential consumer goods) also is prohibited. There are no quantitative restrictions on other imports. Most bilateral agree- ments, however, specify quotas (and sometimes prices) for commodities to be traded, and the Government facilitates the fu l f i l lment of the commitments under- taken in the agreements. On the whole, trade with b i la te ral agreement countries is carried out on a com- pensation basis and usually both imports and exports are arranged by the same trader; imports against exports of cotton and wool are carried out by the Gov- ernment or government agencies, or the proceeds of exports are allocated for the Government's external debt servicing. 1 Bulgaria, mainland China, Czechoslovakia, Poland, the U. S. S. R., and Yugoslavia. There is also a bilateral payments arrangement with Ind ia under which the bulk of trade is settled through a special account maintained in inconvertible Indian rupees. 19 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution AFGHANISTAN Exchange is provided at the official rate for imports by the Government. Payments for imports through the banking system may be made only under letters of credit, against which a deposit of 100 per cent of the value of the imports in afghanis calculated at the pre- vailing free market rate, or in foreign exchange, is required upon establishment of the letter of credit. Such deposits may be used as collateral to obtain loans from commercial banks. The Afghanistan Bank is authorized to refuse to sell foreign exchange for the importation of a group of consumer goods that are regarded as nonessential. However, exchange for these items may be purchased either from the commercial banks or in the bazaar. Payments for Invisibles Central government payments for foreign debt serv- ice and other invisibles are made at the official rate. All other payments are settled at free market rates. Travelers leaving Afghanistan may take out not more than Af 500 in Afghan banknotes. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports are not subject to license. Exports of a few commodities (e.g., opium and museum pieces) are pro- hibited. Otherwise, control is exercised only over exports to bilateral agreement countries (see section on Imports and Import Payments, above). However, exporters of cotton are required to sell at least 20 per cent of their total exports to countries from which pay- ments will be received in convertible currencies. Kar- akul is not exported to payments agreement countries. Exchange receipts from exports of karakul, wool, and cotton must be surrendered at the official rate, irrespective of destination. The net proceeds of all exports other than karakul, wool, and cotton, irrespec- tive of the currency in which they accrue, must either be sold at free market rates to a domestic bank or be used by the exporter or a third party to pay for imports. Export receipts from cotton are subject to an exchange subsidy at the rate of Af 25 per US$1 for convertible currency receipts and Af 3.12 per US$1 for exports settled under bilateral payments agreements. Convertible currency receipts from wool exports are paid an exchange subsidy at the rate of Af 10 per US$1 and those from karakul exports are paid an exchange subsidy of Af 20 per US$1. Proceeds from the export of walnuts received over bilateral payments accounts are subject to an exchange tax of 9.5 per cent. Proceeds from Invisibles Thirty per cent of the foreign currency salaries of foreign employees of the Afghan public and private 20 sectors must be converted into afghanis at the official rate, but the rema in ing 70 per cent may be remitted abroad or exchanged at the free market rate. Except in the case of India, receipts over bilateral payments agreement accounts f rom the embassies and state trad- ing organizations of the countries concerned for their local expenses in Afghanistan are converted at the official rate. All other receipts f rom invisibles are sold at free market rates through either the banks or the bazaar. Travelers entering Afghanistan may bring in Afghan banknotes not exceeding Af 500. Capital Foreign investment in Afghanistan requires prior approval and is administered, as is domestic private investment, by an Investment Committee composed of five cabinet ministers. The Foreign and Domestic Pri- vate Investment Law (February 10, 1967) provides for a number of benefits, which include (1) income tax exemption for five years, beginning from the date of the first sales of products resulting from the new investment; (2) exemption from import duties on essential imports for five consecutive years after approval of the investment; (3) exemption from taxes on dividends for five years after the first distribution of dividends, but not more than eight years after the approval of the investment; (4) exemption from per- sonal income tax and corporate tax on interest on for- eign loans which constitute part of an approved invest- ment; (5) exemption from export duties for ten years after the approval of the investment; and (6) mandatory purchases by government agencies and departments of their requirements from enterprises established under the law where such products are substantially competi- tive with imports in price and quality. The law also establishes that an investment approved by the Invest- ment Committee shall require no further license to operate in Afghanistan. Principal and interest installments on loans from abroad may be remitted freely to the extent of the legal obligation involved. Profits may be repatriated freely, and capital may be repatriated after five years at an annual rate not exceeding 25 per cent of the total registered capital. All the foregoing transfers are made through the free market. Joint ventures of foreign and Afghan capital are encouraged, but no specific percent- ages of domestic participation are prescribed and 100 per cent foreign-owned investments are not precluded by law. Gold Residents may freely import and purchase, hold, and sell domestically gold in any form. Exports of gold and silver in any form other than jewelry require licenses issued by the Council of Ministers; such licenses are ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution AFGHANISTAN not normally granted except for exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and industrial users. Commercial exports of gold and silver jewelry and of other articles containing minor quantities of gold or silver do not require a license and may be made freely. Customs duties are payable on imports and exports of silver in any form, unless the import or export is made by or on behalf of the monetary authorities. The import duty on gold is 1 per cent. Not for Redistribution ALGERIA Exchange Rate System No par value for the currency of Algeria has been established with the Fund. The official unit of currency is the Algerian Dinar. The exchange rate for the French f r anc is a fixed rate of D AI = F 1.12499, giving the relationship DA 4.93706 = US$1. The Cen- tral Bank of Algeria deals in French francs and the other French Franc Area currencies at fixed rates, free of commissions or charges. Buying and selling rates for specified currencies of countries outside the French Franc Area x are established by the Central Bank of Algeria on the basis of the daily rates quoted on the Paris exchange market for these currencies. The exchange rate applicable to "agreement dollars" is the average rate for the U.S. dollar in the Paris market on the day preceding the en try on the clearing account. The predevaluation rate for the French franc and the prerevaluation rate for the deutsche mark are applica- ble to certain payments or receipts in the respective currencies. The Central Bank charges on its transac- tions in non-Franc Area currencies a commission rang- ing from 0.2 per mill to 1.5 per mill, depending on the na tu re of the transaction, and a tax of 6 per cent on the amount of the commission. The foreign exchange reserves are centralized in the Central Bank; authorized banks must clear their foreign currency position with their correspondents in the French Franc Area at the end of each day but they are under certain condi- tions permitted to hold outside the French Franc Area cover for documentary credits. There are no forward exchange facilities. Administration of Control The Ministry of Finance and the Central Bank have general jurisdiction over exchange control. The Cen- tral Bank of Algeria assists in the formulation of the exchange legislation and regulations and is responsible for their execution and for their application by the authorized banks. In addition, three commercial banks and the Postal Administration have been given author- ity to carry out some of the detail of exchange control. Import and export licenses for all commodities are issued on the advice of the competent ministry by the Ministry of Commerce and require the visa of the Cen- tral Bank. The Societe Nationale pour la Recherche, la Production, le Transport, la Transformation et la Com- mercialisation des Hydrocarbures (SONATRACH) has a monopoly over imports and domestic sales of petro- leum and petroleum products. Investment of foreign capital in excess of DA 500,000 in Algeria requires approval by a National Investment Committee in order to obtain the benefits of the Investment Code.
