Central Bank Circular No. 222 reduced the limits on sales of foreign exchange for travel by 50 per cent. The new limits were US$50 a person for each trip to Brazil and Argentina; the equivalent of the fare for travel to Chile, Colom- bia, Mexico, Peru, and Venezuela, with up to 10 per cent granted in foreign currency and the balance in drafts payable through the reciprocal credit agreement with the country concerned; the equivalent of the fare for travel to other countries, with up to 10 per cent available in foreign currency, up to 40 per cent in trav- elers checks, and the balance to be taken up in non- transferable draf ts drawn in the passenger's name; and the equivalent of 30 per cent of the fa re for ship cruises, with up to 10 per cent available in foreign cur- rency and the balance in travelers checks. In addition, purchases of exchange for travel could only be made once every 30 days. December 31. Central Bank Circular No. 223 estab- lished new prepayments for imports during the period January 1-June 30, 1971, modifying in certain respects the provisions established by Circular No. 204 of Sep- tember 17. In the first half of 1971, imports free of prepayments would in principle be limited to 35 per 464 cent of 1970 import registrations. For imports free of surcharge, or subject to a surcharge of 5 per cent, 15 per cent, or 35 per cent, a prepayment of 150 per cent (105 per cent on imports from LAFTA countries) was applied on any imports in excess of 35 per cent of the value of total import declarations presented by each im- porter during 1970; the value of import declarations was to comprise all imports effected in the base period, whether within the quota free of prepayments or with prepayments, excluding only the value of tea (yerba mate). For imports subject to surcharges of 65 per cent or 95 per cent, a prepayment of 300 per cent (210 per cent for LAFTA countries) was required on the value of imports over 35 per cent of the value of total 1970 import declarations. For imports subject to surcharges of 155 per cent or more, the prepayment required was 400 per cent (280 per cent for LAFTA countries) on imports over 35 per cent of declarations in the same base period. Goods in the first of these categories, when imported by industrial importers for their own use, obtained a 20 per cent reduction in the prepayment applied. Imports of capital goods would be subject to a different prepayment schedule, depending upon the length of maturity of the financing obtained. Author- ized imports of specified capital goods financed at more than three years' maturity were exempt from prepay- ments. Those financed at less than three years' term were subject to prepayments of 50-150 per cent (35-105 per cent on imports from LAFTA countries). Capital goods included in the special list but not authorized by the Central Bank were subject to prepay- ments of 225 per cent (155 per cent on imports from LAFTA countries). Moreover, imports of capital goods up to US$10,000 per importer per calendar quarter were exempt from prepayments. Imports for which no foreign exchange transfer was involved, those with tax and customs duty exemptions, and those financed with loans of ten years' maturity or more from international agencies or foreign governments, were exempt. Also included in the list of exemptions were imports of capi- tal goods when such imports were deemed to be neces- sary for economic development, imports of automotive kits authorized by the Automotive Commission, imports of specified drugs, chemicals, and pharmaceuticals exempt from surcharges or subject to 5 per cent or 15 per cent surcharges when these were deemed necessary, and imports of ju te fabrics. The exemption was also applied to imports from LAFTA countries of goods covered by Uruguay's complimentarity agreements. Finally, the exemption for public sector imports henceforth was limited to those that had obtained the prior approval of the Central Bank; previously, this exemption was automatic. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution VENEZUELA Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.265275 gram of fine gold per Venezuelan Bolivar or Bs 3.35 = US$1. No transactions take place at the par value. Exchange transactions take place at the following rates.1 The Central Bank of Venezuela purchases proceeds of the petroleum and iron ore exporting companies at the rate of Bs 4.40 per US$1. Any proceeds from exports of cacao and coffee that are offered for sale to the Central Bank must be purchased by it at the rate of Bs 4.485 per US$1. The Central Bank sells exchange to the Government and its agencies and to the commercial banks (for sales to the public only) at Bs 4.485 per US$1.2 The commercial banks purchase foreign exchange from the public at rates close to Bs 4.48 per US$1. Commercial banks must sell exchange to the public at Bs4.50 per US$1 for all transactions. Some foreign exchange is also negotiated on the two stock exchanges, where buying and selling rates usually are slightly below Bs 4.50 per US$1. Exchange houses are permitted to deal only in banknotes, coins, and travelers checks. The Central Bank offers swap facilities under which it buys U. S. dollars at Bs4.47 and resells at Bs 4.50 after 90 or 180 days. Administration of Control There is no exchange control mechanism. Import and export licenses, when required, are generally issued by the Ministry of Development or the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock, depending on the commod- ity. Under the terms of an agreement between the Gov- ernment and the Central Bank, the latter has the responsibility of ensuring that a subsidy is applied to imports of wheat for human consumption and to cer- tain exports of coffee and cacao. Prescription of Currency Payments between Venezuela and Argentina, Chile, Colombia, the Dominican Republic, Mexico, Peru, and Uruguay may be made through accounts maintained with each other by the Central Bank of Venezuela and the central banks of the countries concerned. Proceeds from exports of petroleum and petroleum derivatives must not be received through these accounts. Other- wise, no prescription of currency requirements are in force. iThe exchange rates given (except those for the Central Bank's swap transactions) are those applicable to sight drafts on New York. 2 The Central Bank does not sell foreign exchange to the public but does sell minor amounts to its staff and certain government officials, at the Bs 4.50 rate, for travel expenses and personal remit- tances. Imports and Import Payments The import of certain goods is either prohibited or reserved for the Government; they include fully assem- bled automobiles, certain textiles, coffee, citrus fru i t, bananas, pineapples, melons, salt, opium, cigarette paper, natural pearls, and matches. In addition, many other commodities require import licenses; quantitative restrictions applicable irrespective of origin are main- tained on these items for protective purposes. Licenses are valid for all countries except Rhodesia and South Africa. Import licenses for some products are issued on the condition that the importer has purchased domestic products equal to a prescribed percentage of the quan- tity imported (contingentamiento). Imports of wheat for human consumption receive a subsidy of 25.55 per cent of the f.o.b. value, calculated at Bs 4.50 per US$1; they require an import license, and the Central Bank's Import Subsidy Office establishes eligibility for the sub- sidy. All other commodities are free from import licens- ing. Imports from Rhodesia and South Africa are pro- hibited. Import payments may be made freely. Payments for Invisibles All payments for invisibles may be made freely; private sector purchases of exchange for this purpose are made from commercial banks or exchange houses. Resident and nonresident travelers must on departure pay a travel tax of Bs 80 a person a trip; exemptions exist for children under seven, foreign tourists, Vene- zuelan and foreign diplomats, and personnel of interna- tional organizations. Travelers may freely export domestic and foreign currency. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of certain furs and hides, scrap metals, and a few other commodities are prohibited. Licenses are required for the exportation of most other commodi- ties, except petroleum. Most export licenses are issued by the Ministry of Development, but those for coffee and cacao are granted by the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock. Exports of products containing subsidized imported wheat are subject to special arrangements to ensure that the subsidy received is repaid. The export of gold and precious stones requires an export license issued by the Ministry of Finance. The petroleum and iron ore exporting companies must surrender to the Central Bank export proceeds, to the extent of their local cur- rency requirements (including taxes), at a rate of Bs4.40 per US$1. Otherwise, there are no surrender requirements for export proceeds or other exchange receipts. Exporters of coffee and cacao may (but need 465 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution VENEZUELA not) sell exchange proceeds to the Central Bank at Bs 4.485 per US$1; they may receive an export subsidy calculated to prevent the f.o.b. bolivar prices of these products in Venezuelan ports from falling below speci- fied minimum amounts regardless of external prices for these products. Eligibility for this subsidy is maintained also if the exchange proceeds are not surrendered. The minimum prices guaranteed by the Government range from Bs 175.00 to Bs 185.44 a quintal for coffee, and are Bs 121 or Bs 150 a quintal for cacao. In principle, the benefit of these arrangements may be extended to firms processing domestic coffee or cacao for export. Exports to Rhodesia and South Africa are prohib- ited. Proceeds from Invisibles Exchange receipts from invisibles are freely dispos- able. Travelers may freely import domestic and foreign currency, with the exception that the Currency Law prohibits the importation for commercial purposes of foreign coins other than gold coins. The importation of Venezuelan gold coins is reserved for the Central Bank. Capital All capital transfers are permitted freely. Brokerage activity in Venezuela, however, in shares or units of foreign investment trusts or mutual funds is prohibited. There is no registration procedure for incoming capital. The Central Bank regulates bank credit to nonresidents and companies whose capital is more than 50 per cent owned by physical persons or companies that are resi- dent or domiciled abroad. The Banking Law of Decem- ber 30, 1970 authorizes the Government to regulate bank credit to companies whose capital is more than 40 per cent owned by nonresident or foreign physical persons or companies. This law also provides special regulations for foreign banks operating in Venezuela. Gold Venezuelan gold coins are legal tender but do not circulate. Residents may hold, acquire, and sell gold coins in Venezuela for numismatic and investment pur- poses. The Central Bank does not deal in gold with the public, but gold coins, medallions, and bars are freely negotiated between licensed importers, exchange houses, and the public. Commercial banks may freely negotiate gold coins among themselves and with other residents but do not normally deal in gold with the public. Imports and exports of monetary gold are reserved for the Central Bank, as is the import of gold coins that are legal tender in Venezuela. Other imports and exports of gold require licenses. Imports require licenses from the Ministry of Finance and in certain cases also from the Ministry of Development, while exports are licensed by the Ministry of Finance only. 466 The law prescribes a license for all imports and exports of gold by anyone not registered at the Ministry of Development as an industrial user, but in practice imports and exports by private persons are permitted free of license. Imports of gold coins and of gold bars and ingots weighing more than 12 kilograms are free of customs duty; all other gold imports are subject to duty at varying rates. All imports of nonmonetary gold are subject to consular duties ranging from 2 per cent to 3V2 per cent ad valorem. Changes during 1970 In addition to the measures specified below, a number of commodities were added to the list of goods that require an individual import license. January 1. Imports of fodder wheat ceased to be entitled to the exchange subsidy of Bs 1.15 per US$1, which continued in force, however, for wheat for human consumption. The issuance of import licenses for fodder wheat ceased to be conditional on purchases of domestic feedstuffs. January 1. A reciprocal credit agreement with the Dominican Republic went into operation. The agree- ment had formally entered into force on July 1, 1968. February 18. Decree No. 246 revised some of the guaranteed prices for exporters of coffee and cacao. The minimum prices henceforth ranged from Bs 175.00 to Bs 185.44 a quintal for four grades of coffee and were Bs 121 or Bs 150 a quintal for two grades of cacao. The Central Bank again was charged with the technical implementation of the subsidy arrangements. Articles 3 and 9 of Decree No. 1159 of January 18, 1964 were revoked. February 18. December 30. A new Banking Law was enacted. 467 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution VIET-NAM Exchange Rate System No par value for the Vietnamese Piastre has been established with the Fund. The official parity is VN$80.00 per US$1. No sales or purchases of exchange take place at the official rate. There are two exchange markets, both with fixed exchange rates: the official market and the limited parallel market. Through the official market pass the following transac- tions: all imports financed with foreign aid funds and some imports financed with Viet-Nam's own foreign exchange or French export credit; transactions on behalf of the Vietnamese and foreign governments for official purposes; transfers to Vietnamese students and civilian and military personnel abroad; and freight, insurance, and incidental expenses on imports. The application of a consolidation premium or a consolida- tion tax of VN$38.00 per US$1 to the official rate gives rise to effective exchange rates of VN$117.20 buying, and VN$118.80 selling, per US$1, and the application of equalization taxes (taxes de per equation) to the VN$118.80 rate results in effective selling rates ranging from VN$125.80 to VN$468.80 per US$1 for specified imports. Through the limited parallel exchange market pass the following transactions: all exports; specified imports financed with Viet-Nam's own foreign exchange or French export credit; and all invisible and capital transactions except those specified above. The rate in this market is fixed at VN$275.00 per US$1, with buying and selling rates of VN$272.25 and VN$277.75 per US$1. An effective buying rate of VN$269.53 results from the application of a 1 per cent tax on proceeds from rubber exports. Furthermore, the application of equalization taxes to the VN$277.75 rate results in effective selling rates ranging from VN$287.75 to VN$627.75 per US$1 for specified imports. (See Table of Exchange Rates, below.) Rates for currencies other than the U. S. dollar are computed on the basis of their official parities in rela- tion to the effective U. S. dollar rate applied to the transaction concerned. Settlements through the limited parallel market must take place in U. S. dollars, pounds sterling, or French francs. Payments and receipts in either exchange market must be effected through the authorized exchange banks. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the National Bank of Viet-Nam (Directorate-General of Exchange). Most remittances must have the prior approval of the Directorate-General of Exchange; the authority to approve some payments for private invisibles has been delegated to the authorized banks. Imports under the 468 U. S. "Public Aid" program * require no license but are subject to special contracts or procurement procedures. Licenses for other imports financed with U. S. aid are issued by the Ministry of Economy (Directorate of General Trade) and are countersigned by the National Bank (Directorate of Foreign A id ). Licenses for imports financed with Viet-Nam's own exchange are issued by the Ministry of Economy (Directorate of External Trade) and are countersigned by the National Bank (Direc- torate-General of Exchange). However, for imports of a noncommercial character, machinery spare parts, and cultural materials, when valued at US$50 or less, the National Bank (Directorate-General of Exchange) is authorized to grant licenses. Export licenses are issued by the Ministry of Economy (Directorate of External Trade), but they also require the approval of the Directorate-General of Exchange. Prescription of Currency All imports shipped from Hong Kong, irrespective of their origin, must be paid for in sterling. All other imports financed by Viet-Nam's own resources must be settled in U. S. dollars, with the exception of imports f rom France and imports effected within the frame- work of a loan agreement, to both of which special regulations apply. Special rules are also applicable to imports financed by the U. S. Agency for International Development (AID). All other settlements through the official market are made in convertible currencies, mainly in U. S. dollars, pounds sterling, or French francs. There is an inoperative payments agreement with the Republic of Korea. Nonresident Accounts Nonresidents may maintain accounts with banks, subject to the approval of the Directorate-General of Exchange. Nonresident Accounts in Free Piastres may be freely credited with the proceeds of sale of convertible exchange and may be freely debited for most payments to residents. A category of nonresident accounts, called Capital Accounts, covers piastres owned by nonresident for- eigners that may not be transferred abroad. Balances in Capital Accounts may be used for investment in certain areas of economic activity designated by the Ministry of National Economy. Their use is subject to the approval of the Directorate-General of Exchange. Investments financed from Capital Accounts generally are not covered by the Investment Law of 1963 (see 1 I.e., imports under the Dollar Project, under part of the AID program, under Development Loan Funds, and under Titles II and III of U.S. P.L. 480. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution section on Capital, be low), and proceeds f rom the liq- uidation of such investments are credited to Capital Accounts unless the Ministry of National Economy has declared them eligible for the privileges of the law. Balances in Capital Accounts are negotiable between nonresident foreigners. Imports and Import Payments Most imports are made in accordance with an annual commercial import program, the bu lk of which is divided into three parts: (1) imports financed with funds from the U. S. AID; (2) imports financed f rom Viet-Nam's own foreign exchange resources; and (3) "third-country-financed imports," i.e., imports financed with Japanese reparations, French, German, and Japa- nese loans, or French export credit. In principle, prod- ucts imported under the AID program are not included among imports that are financed otherwise, and vice versa. However, when AID financing proves insufficient for obtaining imports of essential products, such imports may be financed from Viet-Nam's official exchange reserves. Many imports are prohibited. Indi- vidual import licenses, which are not transferable, are required for practically all imports. With respect to imports financed with Viet-Nam's own foreign exchange the Ministry of Economy issues periodically a Credit Release Order specifying the amount of foreign exchange to be released, the time period for securing import licenses, and a list showing the types and value of commodities eligible for financing with Viet-Nam's own exchange. Applications for import licenses for commodities not included in the list are not considered. The granting of an import license for goods financed with Viet-Nam's own exchange and for specified imports under the U. S. AID and French FRANCEFI pro- grams is subject to advance deposit requirements. For the former category of imports, the applicable amounts of advance deposits are fixed in each Credit Release Order; for the latter category, the amounts of advance deposits are fixed by a circular of the Ministry of Economy. The deposits are established in terms of Vietnamese piastres for each U. S. dollar applied for in the import license and are payable by the importers at the time of application for import licenses to the authorized banks, which forward the applications to the Ministry of Economy. Some imports are permitted without foreign exchange (sans devises); these include imports by end- users with branches abroad, gifts and samples, spare parts for international airlines, and other small imports, when the Directorate-General of Exchange is satisfied that the foreign exchange privately held by the importer has not been obtained illegally. Imports from the Khmer Republic are suspended. Import licenses generally are valid for all noncommu- VIET-NAM nist countries except the Khmer Republic; the main exception is that certain goods financed by U. S. aid must originate in specified noncommunist countries ( the Republic of China, India, the Republic of Korea, Morocco, Pakistan, the Philippines, Singapore, Tunisia, or the United States). Licenses for imports from the United States are valid for eight months, those for imports from Europe and Africa for six months, and those for other areas for four months. Import licenses under programs financed by the U. S. AID are not issued for shipments valued at less than US$5,000. No m in imum value is imposed on licenses for imports financed with Viet-Nam's own foreign exchange. Penalties for underutilization apply when less than 90 per cent of the value of the import license is used. The rate of penalty is VN$10 for each unutilized U. S. dollar. All imports financed with Viet-Nam's own foreign exchange and valued at VN$ 10,000 or over require a letter of credit. In addition to the advance deposit requirements mentioned above, mandatory margin deposits are prescribed on the opening of import letters of credit for most commodities; depending on the goods involved, these deposits are 25, 35, and 50 per cent. They are calculated on the countervalue at the applicable exchange rate of the invoice price plus the applicable equalization tax. Although the minimum margins are set at 25, 35, and 50 per cent, commercial banks are free to apply higher margins according to the standing of the importer and the market situation for the commodity concerned. Some essential commodities are exempt from margin deposit requirements; these include flour, milk, sugar, newsprint, petroleum prod- ucts, fertilizers, agricultural implements, and raw mate- rials and industrial equipment imported by end-users. Some imports are subject to a different type of deposit (consignation). An import license constitutes at the same time an exchange license. Exchange, when granted, is made available either at the limited parallel market rate or at the official rate plus a Consolidation Tax of VN$38 per US$1. An "austerity" tax, ranging from 5 per cent to 750 per cent and payable upon customs clearance, is charged on the c.i.f. value of nonessential or competitive imports calculated at the official rate of exchange. Many imports also are subject to an equalization tax, ranging from VN$10 to VN$350 per US$1 and payable upon the opening of a letter of credit, when they are financed with Viet-Nam's own foreign exchange or sans devises; most imports financed by foreign aid are exempt from this tax. Payments for Invisibles Most payments for invisibles require approval by the Directorate-General of Exchange. Exchange for govern- ment transfers, for transfers to Vietnamese students 469 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution VIET-NAM and public servants on mission or in training abroad, and for freight, insurance, and incidental expenses on imports is sold at the official rate, plus a consolidation tax of VN$38 per US$1. For all other authorized pay- ments for invisibles, exchange is sold at the limited parallel market rate. Students are granted US$80 a month for study in the Republic of China or Hong Kong, and US$150 a month for study elsewhere; they are also granted allocations for housing and for extra- ordinary expenses. Foreign specialists employed in Viet- Nam may transfer at least 35 per cent of their salary every month, and applications for larger transfers may be approved; they are also entitled to a special alloca- tion for home leave. In principle foreign firms are generally permitted to transfer up to 70 per cent of their net annual profit after tax, after examination of their accounts and after deduction of any losses in previous years. Profit transfers by foreign enterprises established or expanded after 1963 under the terms of the 1963 Investment Law are governed by the provisions of that law (see section on Capital, below). All dividends declared in Viet-Nam and accruing to nonresidents may in principle be trans- ferred in full, after payment of taxes. Resident nationals may once a year take a trip abroad, for a maximum period of three months. Each resident national authorized to travel abroad is entitled to purchase the following amounts of foreign exchange at the limited parallel market rate: (a) US$200 if the duration of the trip is less than one month or US$300 if it is one month or more; and (b) for medical treat- ment, US$500 a month. Vietnamese nationals are required to pay the following exit visa fees— VN$50,000 for each country visited, if the duration of the stay is less than one month; VN$75,000 for each country visited, if the duration of the stay is more than one month and less than two months; and VN$ 100,000 for each country visited, if the duration of the stay is more than two months. Children under ten years of age must pay half of these fees. Exit visas for more than three months are not granted. The allocations men- tioned may be supplemented by the equivalent of US$40 in foreign banknotes. Travelers are permitted to take with them up to VN$ 1,000 in Vietnamese bank- notes. Foreign exchange not used by foreign travelers may be re-exported when a declaration is made to the customs and evidence is given that any utilized exchange has been sold to an authorized bank. Exports and Export Proceeds All permitted exports require a license; they must be registered with an authorized bank, which is responsi- ble for the repatriation of the foreign exchange. All exports to communist countries and exports to any des- tination of manufactured or semimanufactured prod- 470 ucts originally imported into Viet-Nam, gold, rice, rice products, and certain other items are prohibited. Export proceeds must be surrendered at the limited parallel market rate. Export proceeds of rubber are subject to a tax of 1 per cent on the f.o.b. value calcu- lated at the limited parallel market rate of exchange. Proceeds from Invisibles The official rate is applicable to invisible receipts arising from sales of foreign exchange by the Vietnam- ese and foreign governments. All other proceeds from invisibles must be surrendered at the limited parallel market rate. Foreign military personnel and official U. S. civilian personnel serving in Viet-Nam are paid in scrip ("mili- tary payment certificates" or MFCs) which can be exchanged for piastres at the limited parallel market rate, only through official channels. They are not per- mitted to possess foreign banknotes or travelers checks in Viet-Nam, but there are military banking facilities under which eligible foreign persons may open accounts in piastres, MFCs, or U. S. dollars at two U. S. banks in Saigon. Travelers entering Viet-Nam may bring in any amount of foreign exchange, but it must be declared to the customs upon entry. A traveler may bring in Viet- namese banknotes up to a total of VN$ 1,000. Foreign military and civilian personnel (government officials) are not permitted to bring foreign banknotes into Viet- Nam. Capital Under general regulations, capital may be imported without formalities, but foreign investors must register their capital with the Vietnamese authorities and agree on the terms of the investment in order to be able to repatriate their capital and to transfer profits. Under the Investment Law of 1963, special benefits may be accorded to new foreign investments in the sectors of the economy that are given high priority. Applications must be approved by the interdepartmental Investment Committee. The minimum investment in agriculture was established at VN$0.5 million, and in industry at VN$1 million. Imports of equipment and spare parts needed by foreign undertakings covered by the law are exempt from customs duties. Foreign technicians employed by these enterprises are exempt from income tax for 2 years. Foreign investments are free of taxes on profits, securities, and real estate for specified peri- ods of time. The new investments are not subject to any nationalization measures for the first 15 years from the date of the written authorization granted to the investor; they are accorded the same treatment as that applicable to domestic investments. The law provides for the transfer of profits at an annual rate of up to 20 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution per cent of the invested capital, and for the repatria- tion of the original investment a f ter 5 years at an annual rate of up to 20 per cent if the capital is newly imported (a f ter 20 years for investment of foreign- owned capital previously held in V ie t -Nam ). All imports and exports of capital ( inc lud ing imports in k ind ), except those made by the Vietnamese Govern- ment or foreign governments, are settled at the limited parallel market rate. Investments not covered by the Investment Law are subject to the regulations and case-to-case decisions of the Directorate-General of Exchange, which normally authorizes the transfer of up to 70 per cent of net annual profits after taxes but does not permit disinvest- ment; such investments are not eligible for the above- mentioned tax exemptions. Gold Within Viet-Nam, the holding of gold and all trans- actions in gold are subject to licensing, but the controls are not rigidly enforced and unlicensed holdings of gold by individuals are tolerated. Only the National Table of Exchange Rates (as at December 31, 1970) VIET-NAM Bank is empowered to import and export gold. All domestic t ransac t ions in gold are subject to a luxu ry tax of 10 per cent on the sale value or the manufac tur- ing cost. The export of gold by physical or jur id ical persons o ther than the National Bank is prohibited. The import of gold by physical or jur id ical persons other than the Na t ional Bank is also prohibited, with the fo l low ing exceptions: (1) Vietnamese settled in Laos may, when re turn ing to Viet-Nam, bring in up to 13 taels 2 of gold in the form of jewelry; (2) residents may import gold w i thout allocation of foreign exchange, provided that they have an import license and pay a customs duty of 130 per cent and an auster- ity tax of 150 per cent as well as an equalization tax of VN$100 per US$1; (3) nonresidents may, without allocation of foreign exchange, bring into Viet-Nam any quan t i ty of gold, provided that its entry is declared and that it is deposited in safe custody with an author- ized bank; the utilization of such gold is subject to prior authorization by the Directorate-General of Exchange, and if it is sold in Viet-Nam the sales pro- ceeds must be credited to a Capital Account. Not for Redistribution YEMEN ARAB REPUBLIC Exchange Rate System The currency of the Yemen Arab Republic is the Yemen Rial, which is issued by the Yemen Currency Board and is defined as equal to 0.829427 gram of fine gold, equivalent to about US$0.93. No par value has been established with the Fund. All transactions take place in a free market at a fluctuating exchange rate; on December 31, 1970 the rate for the U. S. dollar was about YRls 5.5 per US$1.2 The Yemen Bank for Recon- struction and Development charges a fee of YRls 0.05 per <£ stg. 1 on sales of foreign exchange to the private sector and sells exchange for travel and personal remit- tances to its staff at the market rate minus 10 per cent. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Foreign Exchange Control Board in collaboration with the Yemen Bank for Reconstruction and Development (YBRD ), a public sector organization which is the only commercial bank in the country and the only authorized dealer in foreign exchange. The authority to grant exchange licenses and licenses for imports and exports rests with the Board. Prescription of Currency Settlements under bilateral payments arrangements 3 are made in the currencies and through the accounts provided for by these arrangements. Otherwise, settle- ments are usually made in pounds sterling or U. S. dollars. Imports and Import Payments Imports f rom Israel are prohibited. Imports of a few commodities are reserved for the Government. All other imports require import licenses. These are in principle issued in accordance with a list of authorized imports which was established by Decree No. 1 of January 1969 and is reviewed periodically, but licenses are issued freely for all commodities for which govern- ment agencies do not have the exclusive right of impor- tation. Importers who have obtained an import license from the YBRD may obtain the necessary foreign exchange from the free market, provided that they open a letter of credit with the Bank and deposit with the 1 The Yemen Arab Republic became a member of the Internationa] Mone tary Fund on May 22, 1970. - There is usually a small d ifference between the f ree market rate in the Yemen Bank for Reconstruction and Development (the "Bulle- tin rate" or "Bank rate") and that in the bazaar. :| The Yemen Arab Republic ma in ta ins a bilateral paymen ts arrangement with the United Arab Republic. 474 latter foreign exchange equivalent to 50 per cent of the import value within one month. Imports that are financed by the importer with his own foreign exchange held abroad do not require an import license and are exempt from the letter of credit and the deposit requirement. In addition to the applicable customs duty, imports are subject to a defense tax of 5 per cent ad valorem and a statistical tax of 2 per cent ad valorem. Payments for Invisibles All payments in respect of invisibles require an exchange license issued by the Exchange Control Board. Remittances of savings by expatriates are per- mitted up to 50 per cent of annual salary; they may also remit up to the equivalent of <£ stg. 30 a child a mon th for educational purposes. For tourist travel, the Exchange Control Board authorizes foreign exchange according to the merits of the application. For business travel, authorization is freely granted. Travelers require the prior authorization of the Minister of Economy and of the Currency Board to take out Yemen currency in excess of YRls 200 or any foreign currency. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Israel are prohibited. All exports require export licenses. Exporters are in principle required to surrender the foreign exchange proceeds within three months from shipment. In practice, the surrender requirement for exports of cotton, coffee, salt, and hides and skins is 50 per cent, payable within three months from shipment. Proceeds from qat exports are subject to 100 per cent surrender in Southern Yemen dinars within 15 days from shipment, a 5 per cent initial deposit having to be made at the YBRD upon receipt of the license. Other exports (com- prising mainly fruits, fish, and tobacco) are not subject to surrender requirements in cash terms, but the pro- ceeds must be used fully for importing food, and an initial rial deposit of 5 per cent of the export value is required. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from invisibles must in principle be surren- dered but citizens of the Yemen Arab Republic may ma in ta in foreign currency deposit accounts with the YBRD. The import of foreign exchange (whether in the form of gold, silver, currency, or draf ts) and of banknotes of the Yemen Arab Republic requires the prior authorization of the Minister of Economy, but foreign nationals and nonresidents are exempt from these provisions. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Capital All capital transfers require prior approval and capi- tal proceeds must be surrendered. Both domestic and foreign investment are regulated by Law No. 13 of 1970. Foreign investors in the Yemen Arab Republic are free to transfer abroad any desired proportion of their net profits after taxes or capital. Gold A 20-rial gold coin has been issued, which is not legal tender and does not circulate in the Yemen Arab Repub- lic. Dealings in gold are governed by Regulation No. 5 of 1967. The Regulation stipulates that, apart from deal- ings relating to numismatic or ornamental purposes, residents may not deal in gold except with the authoriza- tion of the Minister of Economy. Residents coming into possession of gold (other than ornaments or numismatic coins) are required to offer it for sale to a licensed gold dealer. Licensed dealers are in turn required to sell any gold so acquired to the YBRD within one week from the date of purchase. Changes during 1970 During the year, the Ministry of Economy issued instructions to the Foreign Exchange Board to grant import licenses freely for all commodities for which government agencies did not have an exclusive right of importation. August 20. A number of special exchange rates that YEMEN ARAB REPUBLIC had been applicable mainly to certain transactions under aid agreements with Eastern European countries and ma in land China were abolished. They included the former official rate of YRls 3 per pound sterling. August 20. Previously, it had to be obtained in the bazaar. November 19. An investment law, Law No. 13, came into force. Not for Redistribution PEOPLE'S DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF YEMEN Exchange Rate System The currency of the People's Democratic Republic of Yemen is the Southern Yemen Dinar, which is issued by the Currency Authority and is defined as equivalent to 2.13281 grams of fine gold, correspond- ing to SYD 1 = US$2.40. No par value has been estab- lished for the Southern Yemen dinar. The Currency Authority's rates for the purchase and sale of pounds sterling in transactions with the public are fixed at % per cent either side of parity, but thus far no dealings have taken place with the public. The rates for the Currency Authority's transactions with authorized banks are set at % per cent either side of parity for transactions up to SYD 100,000 and at %2 per cent either side of parity for transactions exceeding SYD 100,000; dealings in U. S. dollars with authorized banks take place at % per cent either side of parity. A transfer duty of 1 per cent is levied on certain personal remittances and on foreign exchange made available for nonofficial travel (including travelers checks issued by banks). Administration of Control The administration of exchange control is carried out by the Exchange Control Department of the Ministry of Economy and Industry. The Ministry also issues import and export licenses, through its Controller of Civil Supplies, except those for gold, which are issued by the Exchange Controller. Exchange transactions must be carried out through the intermediary of authorized dealers (licensed commercial banks approved by the Exchange Controller). Except for payments for imports against letters of credit or documents, which may be approved by an authorized dealer, and for payments by the oil refinery, all payments to nonresidents require the prior approval of the Exchange Controller. Two public corporations and a semipublic corporation are engaged in foreign trade (see Imports and Import Pay- ments, below). The oil refinery is treated as a nonresi- dent entity and in its operations generally is not affected by the existing exchange and trade controls. Prescription of Currency The People's Democratic Republic of Yemen is a member of the Sterling Area. Exchange transactions must be carried out through the intermediary of authorized dealers in accordance with prescription of currency regulations that are in certain respects similar to those applicable in the United Kingdom. All pay- ments to Israel and Rhodesia are prohibited. Export proceeds and certain receipts from invisibles must be 476 received in prescribed currencies l and surrendered to authorized dealers. Payments for imports must be made in prescribed currencies. Nonresident Accounts Nonresident accounts may be held by certain persons not resident in the People's Democratic Republic of Yemen whether they are resident in or outside the Ster- ling Area. The principal type of nonresident account is the External Account in Southern Yemen Dinars. External Accounts may also be held by certain resi- dents. They may be credited with proceeds from con- vertible foreign currency transferred from abroad, with bank interest payable on such accounts, and with bal- ances from other External Accounts. Transfers from abroad must be in the form of bank drafts; the accounts cannot be credited with payments in the form of foreign banknotes, or with locally raised or locally earned funds. External Accounts may be debited for any payments to residents, for transfers to other Exter- nal Accounts, and for payments abroad in any convert- ible currency. The Exchange Controller may direct any payment to a nonresident to a Blocked Account. Except for invest- ments in prescribed securities, balances in Blocked Accounts cannot be debited without the permission of the Exchange Controller. Securities thus acquired may be dealt with freely. Imports and Import Payments With minor exceptions, all imports other than those of the Government and the oil refinery require individ- ual licenses. Overland merchanting trade with the Yemen Arab Republic is also exempt from the licens- ing requirements. There are special regulations govern- ing merchanting trade with other countries. Imports from Israel and Rhodesia are prohibited. Payments for imports against letters of credit or documentary drafts can be made by authorized dealers without the prior approval of the Exchange Controller; all other forms of payment for imports require such approval. A state Board of Trade, which is a department of the Economic Organization for the Public Sector and National Planning, is in charge of the trading activities of the nationalized companies. The National Company for Foreign Trade has a monopoly over imports of flour, sugar, wheat, rice, ghee, cooking oil, tea, and cig- arettes. The National Import Company Ltd. imports certain consumer goods not mentioned in Law No. 37 of 1969. The National Company for Home Trade is the sole importer of automobiles and other vehicles, all 1 All freely convertible currencies. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution government requirements, and most requirements of the public hospitals. Imports into and exports from the free port zone of Aden are free of exchange and trade controls and are exempt from customs duties. Payments for Invisibles With the exception of certain remittances up to SYD 10,2 all payments for invisibles require prior approval by the Exchange Controller. The basic annual exchange allowance for tourism is the equivalent of SYD 100 in travelers checks and drafts and SYD 100 in foreign notes and coins (50 per cent of these amounts for children under 12). Allowances for other types of travel are granted on the merits of the application. For- eign employees of approved enterprises and the oil refinery are allowed to remit abroad up to 50 per cent and three eighths, respectively, of their total earnings (net of taxes). All insurance is nationalized and existing policies have been transferred to the National Insurance and Reinsurance Company. A transfer duty of 1 per cent applies to purchases of foreign exchange (including travelers checks) for family remittances and for tourist, business, educa- tional, and health travel; official travel allowances are exempt. Travelers may take out the equivalent of SYD 10 in domestic or foreign banknotes and up to the equivalent of SYD 100 in travelers checks. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports except petroleum products require licenses. Exports to Israel and Rhodesia are prohibited. Export proceeds must be received in prescribed currencies within three months of shipment and must be sold to authorized dealers upon receipt. Proceeds from Invisibles All claims of residents for services rendered to non- residents must be collected in foreign currency (or received from an External Account) when due and surrendered to authorized dealers. Travelers may freely bring in foreign banknotes but not more than SYD 10 in domestic currency. Capital Virtually all capital payments and transactions require prior approval. However, external borrowing by nonresident firms operating in Aden is exempt. Resi- dents may freely retain abroad certain capital proceeds, including those from the sale of real property to per- sons resident in the Sterling Area. PEOPLE'S DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF YEMEN mally permitted upon departure to remit their liquid funds to their country of permanent residence. Foreign investments that have been approved under the Foreign Investment Law (Law No. 27 of July 22, 1969) may be granted exemptions from import duty, and various other tax facilities. While all other remittances abroad of interest and profits require prior approval by the Exchange Control- ler, profit remittances abroad by foreign firms approved under Law No. 27 also require the permission of the Minister of Economy and Industry and in any one year should not normally exceed 10 per cent of the capital brought into the People's Democratic Republic of Yemen, although the Minister may approve larger transfers. In general, the remittance of depreciation allowances is not permitted, but for approved foreign investments the Minister may allow the annual transfer of up to 10 per cent of the capital brought in, begin- ning two years after production has started. Interest due on any loans obtained abroad after the firm con- cerned has been established may also be remitted, pro- vided that all duties, taxes, and other government dues have been paid. Gold Only the monetary authorities and authorized dealers may purchase, hold, or sell gold bullion. Licensed gold- smiths may purchase, hold, and sell other unworked gold and gold coins and ornaments up to specified lim- its set by the Exchange Controller. Other residents may hold gold only in the form of ornaments or numismatic coins. Exports and imports of gold by authorized deal- ers require licenses issued by the Exchange Controller; goldsmiths are not permitted to import or export gold and must meet their requirements through authorized dealers. Travelers entering the People's Democratic Republic of Yemen may bring in reasonable amounts of gold in any form; departing travelers may take out reasonable amounts of gold ornaments only. Imports and exports of gold by travelers are subject only to customs control, but incoming travelers must sell to an authorized dealer any gold coins or bullion they carry. Administration of Control On the basis of laws governing these matters, the Federal Executive Council prescribes the general provi- sions in respect of foreign trade and exchange transac- tions. The Federal Secretariat for Foreign Trade, by v ir tue of these general provisions, establishes rules and regulations, makes decisions governing commercial transactions, and issues import and export licenses when required. It is also charged with securing bal- anced trade with payments agreement countries. The Federal Secretariat for Finance prescribes the specific provisions governing exchange transactions. This Secre- tariat and the National Bank of Yugoslavia administer the exchange control. The National Bank prescribes the methods of payment to and from foreign countries; it also licenses compensation transactions. All foreign exchange transactions must be carried out through the National Bank or an authorized bank. The latter are of three types. Fully authorized banks, which must have a minimum foreign exchange credit fund equivalent to US$2 million and an annual exchange turnover of at least US$80 million, may engage in all foreign exchange transactions in Yugosla- via and abroad, as well as in foreign credit operations (including the granting of guarantees). Limited author- ized banks, which must have a minimum foreign exchange credit fund equivalent to US$400,000, may conduct foreign exchange operations in Yugoslavia only; they may neither keep foreign exchange accounts abroad nor engage in foreign credit operations, except through the intermediary of a fully authorized credit bank. Authorized exchange offices may only deal in for- eign banknotes and travelers checks; this status is open to all commercial and savings banks. Commercial exports and imports may be effected by all economic organizations (both producing and trading undertakings) registered for this purpose with district courts. Registration is effected automatically, provided that certain conditions, including the provision of mini- mum working capital for trade enterprises, are fulfilled. Economic organizations that are not registered to con- duct foreign trade channel their orders through eco- nomic organizations which export and/or import on their own behalf. 1 In view of changes that took place on January 1, 1971 (see note at the end of this survey), this survey presents the position on that date. 2 On January 23, 1971 the par value was changed to Din 15.00 = US$1. Payments to and from countries with which Yugosla- via has b i la teral paymen ts agreements are made in the currencies and according to the procedures set fo r th in those agreements. If no agreement exists, settlement is usually made in a convertible currency. Yugoslavia has payments agreements requiring settlements through bilateral accounts as fo l lows: ( 1) in U. S. dollars with Afghanistan, Albania, Algeria, Brazil, Bulgaria, Czecho- slovakia, Eastern Germany, Ghana, Greece, Guinea, Hungary, Mali, Mongolia, Poland, Ruman ia, Turkey, and the U. S. S. R.; and (2) in the ir respective cur- rencies with India and Iraq. Certain settlements with Colombia, Mexico, and Pakistan take place through special accounts. A degree of mu l t i la tera l iza t ion of pay- ments is provided under the bilateral payments agree- ments with Afghanistan, Iraq, and Mali. (The payments agreement with Guinea was terminated on Janua ry 3, 1971 and those with Mali and Turkey on Ap r il 1, 1971.) Nonresident Accounts Foreign juridical and physical persons may maintain accounts denominated in foreign exchange and in dinars in Yugoslavia according to the following rules. Foreigners resident outside Yugoslavia may freely open accounts in convertible currencies in Yugoslavia. For- eign missions and foreigners resident in Yugoslavia may freely open with authorized banks accounts expressed in foreign currencies or dinars. Foreign exchange accounts in convertible currencies of nonresident juridical and physical persons are kept in the currency deposited. Balances on these accounts may be used for all payments in Yugoslavia, in dinars or in the currency concerned, and abroad, in any con- vertible currency. Transfers f rom these accounts are free if made in the currency in which the account is kept; outward transfers in other convertible currencies are subject to the account-holding bank's being pre- pared to make the necessary conversion. Nonresident foreign exchange accounts in bilateral currencies may be opened only for foreign juridical and physical persons resident in Yugoslavia and subject to prior approval by the National Bank. Balances may be used only for dinar payments in Yugoslavia or for re- transfer to the bilateral country to which the account is related. Nonresident juridical and physical persons may also open dinar accounts with authorized banks. These ac- counts may be credited with dinars acquired in Yugo- slavia in accordance with the existing regulations or sub- ject to the approval of the National Bank of Yugoslavia. Balances are in principle nontransferable and may be 479 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution YUGOSLAVIA spent in Yugoslavia only for noncommercial payments by the account holder or by members of his close family, or by the owner and staff of foreign firms if the account holder is a foreign physical person. If balances on these accounts derive from copyright royalties or from work performed in Yugoslavia by foreigners, from pensions and disability allowances of persons who have emigrated from Yugoslavia, or from alimony payments, transfers may be effected in accordance with the exist- ing regulations. Yugoslav resident nationals may maintain foreign exchange accounts with any authorized bank. These ac- counts are interest bearing, and interest is paid in for- eign currency. Foreign exchange accounts may be re- tained for an indefinite period of time and they may be drawn upon freely for payments in Yugoslavia and abroad on behalf of the holder or his immediate family; balances are not transferable, however, to other persons or accounts (see section on Proceeds from Invisibles, below). Yugoslav emigrants residing abroad and former emigrants returning to Yugoslavia may also open for- eign exchange accounts in Yugoslavia that may be used freely for payments in Yugoslavia or abroad. Imports and Import Payments Commercial imports may be effected only by eco- nomic organizations registered as participating in for- eign trade. In addition to economic organizations spe- cializing in foreign trade, most major industrial producers are registered. The import of certain basic foodstuffs, such as wheat, rice, coffee, lard, edible oil, and sugar, is carried out by economic organizations that have been selected by the Federal Office for Agri- cultural Products Reserves, on the basis of public bids, to act as its agents. For most commodities, import licenses are not required. All commodities included in the foreign trade nomenclature are classified in four categories according to the manner in which exchange is made available: LB —liberalized goods; GDK—goods imported under global exchange quotas; RK and DK—goods subject to individual quotas (RK if individual quotas are fixed by quantity and DK if they are fixed in d ina r s ); and D— imports subject to ad hoc licensing. About 1,836 items (out of a total of over 4,500) are classified under LB; protective equipment for workers and all other goods not specifically included in the GDK, RK, DK, or D lists are also liberalized and free from any quantitative restriction. LB goods are mainly raw materials, foodstuffs, and spare parts; they also in- clude some consumer goods. In 1970 goods currently im- ported under the LB regime accounted for 31.2 per cent of total imports. Exchange for payments for LB im- ports from the convertible currency area is made avail- 480 able freely in any convertible currency appropriate to the exporting country. Payments for imports of liberal- ized goods from payments agreement countries must be made in the manner prescribed in the relevant payments agreement and may be restricted according to the avail- ability of funds in the appropriate clearing account. The GDK list comprises most consumer goods, some raw materials, and most capital equipment. In 1970 im- ports of commodities presently on this list amounted to 44.8 per cent of total imports. Such imports can be made under several different procedures. Those for non- consumer goods are as follows. Each importer of raw materials and other reproduction materials receives a global foreign exchange quota and may use the exchange so allocated to purchase any such goods listed as GDK. For certain imports by the metal-working, shipbuilding, electrical, and textile industries the authority to use the allocated foreign exchange quota is dependent on the exports that the importers have made (import-export l ink ing) .3 Major exporters, i.e., exporters whose exports settled in convertible currency account for more than 51 per cent of their total sales proceeds, are permitted to pay freely for imports of raw materials and other reproduction materials for their own needs. Payment for imports of capital goods on the GDK list may be financed from specific exchange allocations; a considerable portion may be freely financed from reten- tion quota funds (see section on Exports and Export Proceeds, be low), funds originating in depreciation allowances, and credits obtained abroad, including sup- pliers' credits. The specific exchange allocations are limited mainly to large investment projects, including public utilities; the amounts are determined by the Federal Assembly and in 1970 they accounted for 3.8 per cent of total imports of equipment. Economic orga- nizations may acquire foreign exchange not exceeding 10 per cent of their annual depreciation allowance. Certain services may use percentages varying between 30 per cent (ocean and river shipping) and 100 per cent (air transportation). One half of the exchange thus allocated is in convertible and one half in bilateral currency. Imports under commodity quotas (list RK or list DK ), mainly selected agricultural and mineral products (such as wheat, sugar, rice, coffee, and salt) but also cigars, cigarettes, and machine tools, are subject to maximum quotas established for each commodity and cannot be imported under any other procedure. The quotas are established either in physical quantities (RK) or in dinars (DK ). There are separate quotas in each case for imports from convertible area countries and payments agreement countries; their allocation among importers is decided by negotiations among the 8 This system is also applied to certain DK imports. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution economic organizations.4 Imports of present RK and DK items amounted to 17.9 per cent of imports in 1970. Goods in list D comprise gunpowder, ammunition, opium, motor vehicles, tractors, certain textile fibers and yarns, television sets, railroad rolling stock, and a i rc ra f t. Import licenses are required only for list D commodities. Such licenses do not imply the right to purchase fore ign exchange; the economic organizations must supply the exchange from their global exchange quotas or retention quotas. Imports of D items accounted for 6.1 per cent of total imports in 1970. For certain goods there is an additional requirement, irrespective of those set out above, for a special import license ("accordance") issued by the Federal Secretar- iat for Foreign Trade. These goods are 89 LB items, 73 GDK items, and 25 RK items. For all 187 items, the Secretariat may prescribe direct importation from the country of origin; these items include a wide range of tropical foodstuffs and fruits, raw materials, fats, oils, and textiles, as well as tin and raw cotton. (On June 3, 1971 the accordance requirement was restricted to 24 LB items, 26 GDK items, and 4 RK items.) Private persons who are Yugoslav nationals and hold foreign exchange accounts with Yugoslav banks may use these funds freely to import goods intended for their own use or the use of close relatives, regardless of the import regime for the goods. Also, Yugoslavs re turn ing from work abroad may import goods intended for their personal needs or the needs of their own household, provided that such goods were paid for from the savings from their foreign earnings; such sav- ings need not be kept on foreign exchange accounts with Yugoslav banks. As an exception to the foregoing, owners of foreign exchange accounts and Yugoslav nationals working abroad may only import motorcars, trucks, motor- cycles, mopeds, and bicycles, together with mounted motors and essential spare parts for these vehicles, through a registered enterprise, provided that payment is made through a foreign exchange account held at a Yugoslav bank. Yugoslav citizens re tu rn ing from a tourist trip abroad may import any amount of goods intended for the needs of their household. However, if the value of the goods exceeds Din 1,000, these goods must be handed over, at the customs office at the point of entry, to a domestic forwarder for delivery to the owner's address; such delivery cannot be made unless the customs duties are paid. Compensation transactions are only authorized in exceptional circumstances; in 1970 they accounted for 0.2 per cent of total imports. At this time 6 they are also required to deposit with an authorized bank an amount in dinars equal in value to the import order. The deposits are not interest bearing and they are used to purchase the foreign exchange for the import payment. Deposits are not required for pay- ments made by debiting foreign exchange accounts of importers. In addition to the above deposit requirement, import- ers are obliged to deposit with an authorized bank dinars equivalent to 20 per cent of the import payment.7 These deposits have to be lodged at the same time as the other deposits mentioned above, and they are released after three months. They are not interest bearing, and have to be made even if payments are made by debiting foreign exchange accounts of importers. Many agricultural commodities and foodstuffs are subject to variable import levies.
